{"timeCrawl": "10:44:00", "uri": "710827558", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T10:44:00Z", "sim": 0.9333333373069763, "source": {"title": "The Sudanese Media Centre", "uri": "smc.sd", "id": "7528"}, "url": "http://smc.sd/en/latest-world-vision-urges-aid-protect-refugee-kidsa/", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "KAMPALA, Uganda -- The Latest on Uganda reaching 1 million refugees from South Sudan (all times local): A World Vision official says more aid is needed to ensure refugee children on the move are protected when they arrive in Uganda.\n\nEnid Kabasinguzi Ocaya, World Vision's s disaster risk reduction and humanitarian emergency affairs manager in Uganda, said in a statement Thursday that \"there is a fear that they may return to South Sudan and take part in the conflict.\"\n\nWorking in partnership with the United Nations, World Vision is the largest provider of food for refugees in Uganda.\n\nOver 85 percent of the South Sudanese refugees sheltering in Uganda are women and children.\n\nThe U.N. said Thursday that the number of South Sudanese refugees in Uganda has reached 1 million.\n\nThe number of South Sudanese refugees sheltering in Uganda has reached 1 million, the United Nations said Thursday, a grim milestone for what has become the world's fastest-growing refugee crisis.\n\nUgandan officials say they are overwhelmed by the flow of people fleeing South Sudan's civil war and the U.N. refugee agency urges the international community to donate more for humanitarian assistance.\n\nAn average of 1,800 South Sudanese citizens have been arriving daily in Uganda over the past 12 months, the UNHCR said in a statement. Another 1 million or more South Sudanese are sheltering in Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Congo and Central African Republic.\n\nThe number of people fleeing jumped after deadly fighting again erupted in South Sudan's capital, Juba, in July 2016.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" the statement said.\n\n\"With refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short.\"\n\nA fundraising summit hosted by Uganda in June raised only a fraction of the $2 billion that Ugandan officials have said is needed to sufficiently look after the refugees and the communities hosting them.\n\n\"This unhappy 1-million milestone must serve as a wake-up call to the international community that much more is needed from them,\" Sarah Jackson, an Amnesty International official in the region, said in a statement Thursday. \"With no resolution to the conflict in South Sudan in sight, refugees will continue to flee to Uganda and the humanitarian crisis will only escalate.\"\n\nMost of the refugees are women and children fleeing violence, often along ethnic lines, since the world's newest country erupted into violence in December 2013.\n\nUgandan refugee officials have repeatedly warned the influx is straining the country's ability to be generous to the refugees, who often are given small plots of land for building temporary shelters and planting crops when they arrive.\n\nThe largest of the settlements hosting refugees from South Sudan, Bidi Bidi, is roughly 230 square kilometers (88.8 sq. miles).\n\nsource:(www.washingtonpost.com)", "id": "9666187", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "The Latest: World Vision Urges Aid to Protect Refugee Kidsa - The Sudanese Media Center", {"timeCrawl": "10:29:00", "uri": "710820519", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T10:29:00Z", "sim": 0.9333333373069763, "source": {"title": "The Globe and Mail", "uri": "theglobeandmail.com", "id": "1409"}, "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/feeds/canadian-press/world/the-latest-1-million-south-sudan-refugees-now-in-uganda/article36008231/", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "The Latest on Uganda reaching 1 million refugees from South Sudan (all times local):\n\n12:30 p.m.\n\nA World Vision official says more aid is needed to ensure refugee children on the move are protected when they arrive in Uganda.\n\nEnid Kabasinguzi Ocaya, World Vision's s disaster risk reduction and humanitarian emergency affairs manager in Uganda, said in a statement Thursday that \"there is a fear that they may return to South Sudan and take part in the conflict.\"\n\nWorking in partnership with the United Nations, World Vision is the largest provider of food for refugees in Uganda.\n\nOver 85 per cent of the South Sudanese refugees sheltering in Uganda are women and children.\n\nThe U.N. said Thursday that the number of South Sudanese refugees in Uganda has reached 1 million.\n\nThe number of South Sudanese refugees sheltering in Uganda has reached 1 million, the United Nations said Thursday, a grim milestone for what has become the world's fastest-growing refugee crisis.\n\nUgandan officials say they are overwhelmed by the flow of people fleeing South Sudan's civil war and the U.N. refugee agency urges the international community to donate more for humanitarian assistance.\n\nAn average of 1,800 South Sudanese citizens have been arriving daily in Uganda over the past 12 months, the UNHCR said in a statement. Another 1 million or more South Sudanese are sheltering in Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Congo and Central African Republic.\n\nThe number of people fleeing jumped after deadly fighting again erupted in South Sudan's capital, Juba, in July 2016.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" the statement said.\n\n\"With refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short.\"\n\nA fundraising summit hosted by Uganda in June raised only a fraction of the $2 billion that Ugandan officials have said is needed to sufficiently look after the refugees and the communities hosting them.\n\n\"This unhappy 1-million milestone must serve as a wake-up call to the international community that much more is needed from them,\" Sarah Jackson, an Amnesty International official in the region, said in a statement Thursday. \"With no resolution to the conflict in South Sudan in sight, refugees will continue to flee to Uganda and the humanitarian crisis will only escalate.\"\n\nMost of the refugees are women and children fleeing violence, often along ethnic lines, since the world's newest country erupted into violence in December 2013.\n\nUgandan refugee officials have repeatedly warned the influx is straining the country's ability to be generous to the refugees, who often are given small plots of land for building temporary shelters and planting crops when they arrive.\n\nThe largest of the settlements hosting refugees from South Sudan, Bidi Bidi, is roughly 230 square kilometres (88.8 sq. miles).\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press journalist Rodney Muhumuza in Kampala, Uganda, contributed to this report.", "id": "9663350", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "The Latest: World Vision {"timeCrawl": "10:29:00", "uri": "710820494", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T10:29:00Z", "sim": 0.9333333373069763, "source": {"title": "Beaumont Enterprise", "uri": "beaumontenterprise.com", "id": "162"}, "url": "http://www.beaumontenterprise.com/news/world/article/The-Latest-1-million-South-Sudan-refugees-now-in-11846926.php", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "KAMPALA, Uganda (AP) -- The Latest on Uganda reaching 1 million refugees from South Sudan (all times local):\n\n12:30 p.m.\n\nA World Vision official says more aid is needed to ensure refugee children on the move are protected when they arrive in Uganda.\n\nEnid Kabasinguzi Ocaya, World Vision's s disaster risk reduction and humanitarian emergency affairs manager in Uganda, said in a statement Thursday that \"there is a fear that they may return to South Sudan and take part in the conflict.\"\n\nWorking in partnership with the United Nations, World Vision is the largest provider of food for refugees in Uganda.\n\nOver 85 percent of the South Sudanese refugees sheltering in Uganda are women and children.\n\nThe U.N. said Thursday that the number of South Sudanese refugees in Uganda has reached 1 million.\n\nThe number of South Sudanese refugees sheltering in Uganda has reached 1 million, the United Nations said Thursday, a grim milestone for what has become the world's fastest-growing refugee crisis.\n\nUgandan officials say they are overwhelmed by the flow of people fleeing South Sudan's civil war and the U.N. refugee agency urges the international community to donate more for humanitarian assistance.\n\nAn average of 1,800 South Sudanese citizens have been arriving daily in Uganda over the past 12 months, the UNHCR said in a statement. Another 1 million or more South Sudanese are sheltering in Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Congo and Central African Republic.\n\nThe number of people fleeing jumped after deadly fighting again erupted in South Sudan's capital, Juba, in July 2016.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" the statement said.\n\n\"With refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short.\"\n\nA fundraising summit hosted by Uganda in June raised only a fraction of the $2 billion that Ugandan officials have said is needed to sufficiently look after the refugees and the communities hosting them.\n\n\"This unhappy 1-million milestone must serve as a wake-up call to the international community that much more is needed from them,\" Sarah Jackson, an Amnesty International official in the region, said in a statement Thursday. \"With no resolution to the conflict in South Sudan in sight, refugees will continue to flee to Uganda and the humanitarian crisis will only escalate.\"\n\nMost of the refugees are women and children fleeing violence, often along ethnic lines, since the world's newest country erupted into violence in December 2013.\n\nUgandan refugee officials have repeatedly warned the influx is straining the country's ability to be generous to the refugees, who often are given small plots of land for building temporary shelters and planting crops when they arrive.\n\nThe largest of the settlements hosting refugees from South Sudan, Bidi Bidi, is roughly 230 square kilometers (88.8 sq. {"timeCrawl": "10:26:00", "uri": "710818933", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T10:26:00Z", "sim": 0.929411768913269, "source": {"title": "WMC Action News 5", "uri": "wmcactionnews5.com", "id": "191"}, "url": "http://www.wmcactionnews5.com/story/36155230/the-latest-world-vision-urges-aid-to-protect-refugee-kids", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "KAMPALA, Uganda (AP) - The Latest on Uganda reaching 1 million refugees from South Sudan (all times local):\n\n12:30 p.m.\n\nA World Vision official says more aid is needed to ensure refugee children on the move are protected when they arrive in Uganda.\n\nEnid Kabasinguzi Ocaya, World Vision's s disaster risk reduction and humanitarian emergency affairs manager in Uganda, said in a statement Thursday that \"there is a fear that they may return to South Sudan and take part in the conflict.\"\n\nWorking in partnership with the United Nations, World Vision is the largest provider of food for refugees in Uganda.\n\nOver 85 percent of the South Sudanese refugees sheltering in Uganda are women and children.\n\nThe U.N. said Thursday that the number of South Sudanese refugees in Uganda has reached 1 million.\n\nThe number of South Sudanese refugees sheltering in Uganda has reached 1 million, the United Nations said Thursday, a grim milestone for what has become the world's fastest-growing refugee crisis.\n\nUgandan officials say they are overwhelmed by the flow of people fleeing South Sudan's civil war and the U.N. refugee agency urges the international community to donate more for humanitarian assistance.\n\nAn average of 1,800 South Sudanese citizens have been arriving daily in Uganda over the past 12 months, the UNHCR said in a statement. Another 1 million or more South Sudanese are sheltering in Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Congo and Central African Republic.\n\nThe number of people fleeing jumped after deadly fighting again erupted in South Sudan's capital, Juba, in July 2016.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" the statement said.\n\n\"With refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short.\"\n\nA fundraising summit hosted by Uganda in June raised only a fraction of the $2 billion that Ugandan officials have said is needed to sufficiently look after the refugees and the communities hosting them.\n\n\"This unhappy 1-million milestone must serve as a wake-up call to the international community that much more is needed from them,\" Sarah Jackson, an Amnesty International official in the region, said in a statement Thursday. \"With no resolution to the conflict in South Sudan in sight, refugees will continue to flee to Uganda and the humanitarian crisis will only escalate.\"\n\nMost of the refugees are women and children fleeing violence, often along ethnic lines, since the world's newest country erupted into violence in December 2013.\n\nUgandan refugee officials have repeatedly warned the influx is straining the country's ability to be generous to the refugees, who often are given small plots of land for building temporary shelters and planting crops when they arrive.\n\nThe largest of the settlements hosting refugees from South Sudan, Bidi Bidi, is roughly 230 square kilometers (88.8 sq. miles).\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press journalist Rodney Muhumuza in Kampala, Uganda, contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. {"timeCrawl": "11:52:00", "uri": "710857999", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T11:52:00Z", "sim": 0.929411768913269, "source": {"title": "WMC Action News 5", "uri": "wmcactionnews5.com", "id": "191"}, "url": "http://www.wmcactionnews5.com/story/36155230/the-latest-south-sudans-displaced-numbers-overwhelming", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "KAMPALA, Uganda (AP) - The Latest on Uganda reaching 1 million refugees from South Sudan (all times local):\n\n2:10 p.m.\n\nThe president of the International Committee of the Red Cross says the number of hungry and displaced South Sudanese is overwhelming.\n\nPeter Maurer said in a statement Thursday there is a \"staggering scale of suffering\" after several years of fighting between government troops and rebel forces in the world's youngest country.\n\nMaurer is visiting South Sudan and later is traveling to neighboring Uganda, where 1 million South Sudanese refugees are now sheltering from the civil war at home.\n\nOver 2 million South Sudanese have fled their country.\n\nThe United Nations is urging the international community to give more toward humanitarian aid for the refugees.\n\nA World Vision official says more aid is needed to ensure refugee children on the move are protected when they arrive in Uganda.\n\nEnid Kabasinguzi Ocaya, World Vision's s disaster risk reduction and humanitarian emergency affairs manager in Uganda, said in a statement Thursday that \"there is a fear that they may return to South Sudan and take part in the conflict.\"\n\nWorking in partnership with the United Nations, World Vision is the largest provider of food for refugees in Uganda.\n\nOver 85 percent of the South Sudanese refugees sheltering in Uganda are women and children.\n\nThe U.N. said Thursday that the number of South Sudanese refugees in Uganda has reached 1 million.\n\nThe number of South Sudanese refugees sheltering in Uganda has reached 1 million, the United Nations said Thursday, a grim milestone for what has become the world's fastest-growing refugee crisis.\n\nUgandan officials say they are overwhelmed by the flow of people fleeing South Sudan's civil war and the U.N. refugee agency urges the international community to donate more for humanitarian assistance.\n\nAn average of 1,800 South Sudanese citizens have been arriving daily in Uganda over the past 12 months, the UNHCR said in a statement. Another 1 million or more South Sudanese are sheltering in Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Congo and Central African Republic.\n\nThe number of people fleeing jumped after deadly fighting again erupted in South Sudan's capital, Juba, in July 2016.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" the statement said.\n\n\"With refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short.\"\n\nA fundraising summit hosted by Uganda in June raised only a fraction of the $2 billion that Ugandan officials have said is needed to sufficiently look after the refugees and the communities hosting them.\n\n\"This unhappy 1-million milestone must serve as a wake-up call to the international community that much more is needed from them,\" Sarah Jackson, an Amnesty International official in the region, said in a statement Thursday. \"With no resolution to the conflict in South Sudan in sight, refugees will continue to flee to Uganda and the humanitarian crisis will only escalate.\"\n\nMost of the refugees are women and children fleeing violence, often along ethnic lines, since the world's newest country erupted into violence in December 2013.\n\nUgandan refugee officials have repeatedly warned the influx is straining the country's ability to be generous to the refugees, who often are given small plots of land for building temporary shelters and planting crops when they arrive.\n\nThe largest of the settlements hosting refugees from South Sudan, Bidi Bidi, is roughly 230 square kilometers (88.8 sq. miles).\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Rodney Muhumuza in Kampala, Uganda, contributed.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"timeCrawl": "11:46:00", "uri": "710855141", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T11:46:00Z", "sim": 0.929411768913269, "source": {"title": "Dothan Eagle", "uri": "dothaneagle.com", "id": "11193"}, "url": "http://www.dothaneagle.com/news/ap/world/the-latest-south-sudan-s-displaced-numbers-overwhelming/article_2aba56d3-7679-5b01-a17f-1171d9ef8671.html", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "KAMPALA, Uganda (AP) -- The Latest on Uganda reaching 1 million refugees from South Sudan (all times local):\n\n2:10 p.m.\n\nThe president of the International Committee of the Red Cross says the number of hungry and displaced South Sudanese is overwhelming.\n\nPeter Maurer said in a statement Thursday there is a \"staggering scale of suffering\" after several years of fighting between government troops and rebel forces in the world's youngest country.\n\nMaurer is visiting South Sudan and later is traveling to neighboring Uganda, where 1 million South Sudanese refugees are now sheltering from the civil war at home.\n\nOver 2 million South Sudanese have fled their country.\n\nThe United Nations is urging the international community to give more toward humanitarian aid for the refugees.\n\n-- -- --\n\n12:30 p.m.\n\nA World Vision official says more aid is needed to ensure refugee children on the move are protected when they arrive in Uganda.\n\nEnid Kabasinguzi Ocaya, World Vision's s disaster risk reduction and humanitarian emergency affairs manager in Uganda, said in a statement Thursday that \"there is a fear that they may return to South Sudan and take part in the conflict.\"\n\nWorking in partnership with the United Nations, World Vision is the largest provider of food for refugees in Uganda.\n\nOver 85 percent of the South Sudanese refugees sheltering in Uganda are women and children.\n\nThe U.N. said Thursday that the number of South Sudanese refugees in Uganda has reached 1 million.\n\n-- -- --\n\n12 p.m.\n\nThe number of South Sudanese refugees sheltering in Uganda has reached 1 million, the United Nations said Thursday, a grim milestone for what has become the world's fastest-growing refugee crisis.\n\nUgandan officials say they are overwhelmed by the flow of people fleeing South Sudan's civil war and the U.N. refugee agency urges the international community to donate more for humanitarian assistance.\n\nAn average of 1,800 South Sudanese citizens have been arriving daily in Uganda over the past 12 months, the UNHCR said in a statement. Another 1 million or more South Sudanese are sheltering in Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Congo and Central African Republic.\n\nThe number of people fleeing jumped after deadly fighting again erupted in South Sudan's capital, Juba, in July 2016.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" the statement said.\n\n\"With refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short.\"\n\nA fundraising summit hosted by Uganda in June raised only a fraction of the $2 billion that Ugandan officials have said is needed to sufficiently look after the refugees and the communities hosting them.\n\n\"This unhappy 1-million milestone must serve as a wake-up call to the international community that much more is needed from them,\" Sarah Jackson, an Amnesty International official in the region, said in a statement Thursday. \"With no resolution to the conflict in South Sudan in sight, refugees will continue to flee to Uganda and the humanitarian crisis will only escalate.\"\n\nMost of the refugees are women and children fleeing violence, often along ethnic lines, since the world's newest country erupted into violence in December 2013.\n\nUgandan refugee officials have repeatedly warned the influx is straining the country's ability to be generous to the refugees, who often are given small plots of land for building temporary shelters and planting crops when they arrive.\n\nThe largest of the settlements hosting refugees from South Sudan, Bidi Bidi, is roughly 230 square kilometers (88.8 sq. {"timeCrawl": "14:19:00", "uri": "710930152", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T14:19:00Z", "sim": 0.9215686321258545, "source": {"title": "The Philadelphia Sunday Sun", "uri": "philasun.com", "id": "13368"}, "url": "http://www.philasun.com/diaspora/1-million-south-sudan-refugees-now-uganda-un-says/", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "KAMPALA, Uganda (AP) -- The number of South Sudanese refugees sheltering in Uganda has reached 1 million, the United Nations said Thursday, a grim milestone for what has become the world's fastest-growing refugee crisis.\n\nUgandan officials say they are overwhelmed by the flow of people fleeing South Sudan's civil war and the U.N. refugee agency urges the international community to donate more for humanitarian assistance.\n\nAn average of 1,800 South Sudanese citizens have been arriving daily in Uganda over the past 12 months, the UNHCR said in a statement. Another 1 million or more South Sudanese are sheltering in Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Congo and Central African Republic.\n\nThe number of people fleeing jumped after deadly fighting again erupted in South Sudan's capital, Juba, in July 2016.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" the statement said.\n\n\"With refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short.\"\n\nA fundraising summit hosted by Uganda in June raised only a fraction of the $2 billion that Ugandan officials have said is needed to sufficiently look after the refugees and the communities hosting them.\n\n\"This unhappy 1-million milestone must serve as a wake-up call to the international community that much more is needed from them,\" Sarah Jackson, an Amnesty International official in the region, said in a statement Thursday. \"With no resolution to the conflict in South Sudan in sight, refugees will continue to flee to Uganda and the humanitarian crisis will only escalate.\"\n\nMost of the refugees are women and children fleeing violence, often along ethnic lines, since the world's newest country erupted into violence in December 2013.\n\nUgandan refugee officials have repeatedly warned the influx is straining the country's ability to be generous to the refugees, who often are given small plots of land for building temporary shelters and planting crops when they arrive.\n\nThe largest of the settlements hosting refugees from South Sudan, Bidi Bidi, is roughly 230 square kilometers (88.8 sq. miles).\n\nThe World Food Program cut food rations for some refugees amid funding shortages in June.\n\nThe U.N. says at least $674 million is needed to support South Sudanese refugees in Uganda this year, although only a fifth of that amount has been received.\n\nThe money is needed to provide basic services, including stocking clinics with medicines and putting up schools. Aid agencies say classroom sizes in the few available schools often exceed 200 pupils, and other children have dropped out because the nearest schools are located miles away.\n\n\"The funding shortfall in Uganda is now significantly impacting the abilities to deliver life-saving aid and key basic services,\" the UNHCR statement said.\n\nFighting persists in parts of South Sudan despite multiple cease-fire agreements. Rebel forces said Tuesday they had reclaimed their stronghold of Pagak in the northeast, less than a week after being pushed out by government forces.\n\nBoth sides have committed serious rights violations, including murder and rape, against civilians, according to U.N. investigators.", "id": "9707890", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "1 million South Sudan refugees now in {"timeCrawl": "09:15:00", "uri": "710786995", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T09:08:00Z", "sim": 0.9176470637321472, "source": {"title": "Associated Press", "uri": "hosted.ap.org", "id": "963"}, "url": "http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/A/AF_SOUTH_SUDAN_1_MILLION_REFUGEES_THE_LATEST?SITE=ORCOO&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "KAMPALA, Uganda (AP) -- The Latest on Uganda reaching 1 million refugees from South Sudan (all times local):\n\n12 p.m.\n\nThe number of South Sudanese refugees sheltering in Uganda has reached 1 million, the United Nations said Thursday, a grim milestone for what has become the world's fastest-growing refugee crisis.\n\nUgandan officials say they are overwhelmed by the flow of people fleeing South Sudan's civil war and the U.N. refugee agency urges the international community to donate more for humanitarian assistance.\n\nAn average of 1,800 South Sudanese citizens have been arriving daily in Uganda over the past 12 months, the UNHCR said in a statement. Another 1 million or more South Sudanese are sheltering in Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Congo and Central African Republic.\n\nThe number of people fleeing jumped after deadly fighting again erupted in South Sudan's capital, Juba, in July 2016.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" the statement said.\n\n\"With refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short.\"\n\nA fundraising summit hosted by Uganda in June raised only a fraction of the $2 billion that Ugandan officials have said is needed to sufficiently look after the refugees and the communities hosting them.\n\n\"This unhappy 1-million milestone must serve as a wake-up call to the international community that much more is needed from them,\" Sarah Jackson, an Amnesty International official in the region, said in a statement Thursday. \"With no resolution to the conflict in South Sudan in sight, refugees will continue to flee to Uganda and the humanitarian crisis will only escalate.\"\n\nMost of the refugees are women and children fleeing violence, often along ethnic lines, since the world's newest country erupted into violence in December 2013.\n\nUgandan refugee officials have repeatedly warned the influx is straining the country's ability to be generous to the refugees, who often are given small plots of land for building temporary shelters and planting crops when they arrive.\n\nThe largest of the settlements hosting refugees from South Sudan, Bidi Bidi, is roughly 230 square kilometers (88.8 sq. miles).\n\n---\n\nAssociated Press journalist Rodney Muhumuza in Kampala, Uganda, contributed to this report.", "id": "9650028", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "The Latest: 1 million {"timeCrawl": "18:09:00", "uri": "711038813", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T18:09:00Z", "sim": 0.9137254953384399, "source": {"title": "Kuwait Times", "uri": "news.kuwaittimes.net", "id": "4037"}, "url": "http://news.kuwaittimes.net/website/un-one-million-s-sudan-refugees-now-uganda/", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "KAMPALA, Uganda: The number of South Sudanese refugees sheltering in Uganda has reached 1 million, the United Nations said yesterday, a grim milestone for what has become the world's fastest-growing refugee crisis. Ugandan officials say they are overwhelmed by the flow of people fleeing South Sudan's civil war and the UN refugee agency urges the international community to donate more for humanitarian assistance. An average of 1,800 South Sudanese citizens have been arriving daily in Uganda over the past 12 months, the UNHCR said in a statement. Another 1 million or more South Sudanese are sheltering in Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Congo and Central African Republic.\n\nThe number of people fleeing jumped after deadly fighting again erupted in South Sudan's capital, Juba, in July 2016. \"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" the statement said.\n\n\"With refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short.\" A fundraising summit hosted by Uganda in June raised only a fraction of the $2 billion that Ugandan officials have said is needed to sufficiently look after the refugees and the communities hosting them.\n\nWake-up call\n\n\"This unhappy 1-million milestone must serve as a wake-up call to the international community that much more is needed from them,\" Sarah Jackson, an Amnesty International official in the region, said in a statement Thursday. \"With no resolution to the conflict in South Sudan in sight, refugees will continue to flee to Uganda and the humanitarian crisis will only escalate.\"\n\nMost of the refugees are women and children fleeing violence, often along ethnic lines, since the world's newest country erupted into violence in December 2013. Ugandan refugee officials have repeatedly warned the influx is straining the country's ability to be generous to the refugees, who often are given small plots of land for building temporary shelters and planting crops when they arrive.\n\nThe largest of the settlements hosting refugees from South Sudan, Bidi Bidi, is roughly 230 square kilometers (88.8 sq. miles). The World Food Program cut food rations for some refugees amid funding shortages in June.\n\nThe UN says at least $674 million is needed to support South Sudanese refugees in Uganda this year, although only a fifth of that amount has been received. The money is needed to provide basic services, including stocking clinics with medicines and putting up schools. Aid agencies say classroom sizes in the few available schools often exceed 200 pupils, and other children have dropped out because the nearest schools are located miles away. \"The funding shortfall in Uganda is now significantly impacting the abilities to deliver life-saving aid and key basic services,\" the UNHCR statement said.\n\nFighting persists in parts of South Sudan despite multiple cease-fire agreements. Rebel forces said Tuesday they had reclaimed their stronghold of Pagak in the northeast, less than a week after being pushed out by government forces. Both sides have committed serious rights violations, including murder and rape, against civilians, according to UN investigators. -AP", "id": "9750199", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": Another 1 million or more South Sudanese are sheltering in Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Congo and Central African Republic.\n\nThe number of people fleeing jumped after deadly fighting again erupted in South Sudan's capital, Juba, in July 2016.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" the statement said.\n\n\"With refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short.\"\n\nA fundraising summit hosted by Uganda in June raised only a fraction of the $2 billion that Ugandan officials have said is needed to sufficiently look after the refugees and the communities hosting them.\n\n\"This unhappy 1-million milestone must serve as a wake-up call to the international community that much more is needed from them,\" Sarah Jackson, an Amnesty International official in the region, said in a statement Thursday. \"With no resolution to the conflict in South Sudan in sight, refugees will continue to flee to Uganda and the humanitarian crisis will only escalate.\"\n\nMost of the refugees are women and children fleeing violence, often along ethnic lines, since the world's newest country erupted into violence in December 2013.\n\nUgandan refugee officials have repeatedly warned the influx is straining the country's ability to be generous to the refugees, who often are given small plots of land for building temporary shelters and planting crops when they arrive.\n\nThe largest of the settlements hosting refugees from South Sudan, Bidi Bidi, is roughly 230 square kilometers (88.8 sq. miles).\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press journalist Rodney Muhumuza in Kampala, Uganda, contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. {"timeCrawl": "09:03:00", "uri": "710782235", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T09:03:00Z", "sim": 0.9098039269447327, "source": {"title": "Federal News Radio", "uri": "federalnewsradio.com", "id": "9518"}, "url": "https://federalnewsradio.com/world-news/2017/08/1-million-south-sudan-refugees-now-in-uganda-un-says/", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "KAMPALA, Uganda (AP) -- The number of South Sudanese refugees sheltering in Uganda has reached 1 million, the United Nations said Thursday, a grim milestone for what has become the world's fastest-growing refugee crisis.\n\nUgandan officials say they are overwhelmed by the flow of people fleeing South Sudan's civil war and the U.N. refugee agency urges the international community to donate more for humanitarian assistance.\n\nAn average of 1,800 South Sudanese citizens have been arriving daily in Uganda over the past 12 months, the UNHCR said in a statement. Another 1 million or more South Sudanese are sheltering in Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Congo and Central African Republic.\n\nThe number of people fleeing jumped after deadly fighting again erupted in South Sudan's capital, Juba, in July 2016.\n\nSponsored Content: How is your agency managing and maximizing its data? Share your opinions in a Federal News Radio survey.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" the statement said.\n\n\"With refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short.\"\n\nA fundraising summit hosted by Uganda in June raised only a fraction of the $2 billion that Ugandan officials have said is needed to sufficiently look after the refugees and the communities hosting them.\n\n\"This unhappy 1-million milestone must serve as a wake-up call to the international community that much more is needed from them,\" Sarah Jackson, an Amnesty International official in the region, said in a statement Thursday. \"With no resolution to the conflict in South Sudan in sight, refugees will continue to flee to Uganda and the humanitarian crisis will only escalate.\"\n\nMost of the refugees are women and children fleeing violence, often along ethnic lines, since the world's newest country erupted into violence in December 2013.\n\nUgandan refugee officials have repeatedly warned the influx is straining the country's ability to be generous to the refugees, who often are given small plots of land for building temporary shelters and planting crops when they arrive.\n\nPostal Service may be able to raise price of stamps this fall\n\nThe largest of the settlements hosting refugees from South Sudan, Bidi Bidi, is roughly 230 square kilometers (88.8 sq. miles).\n\nThe World Food Program cut food rations for some refugees amid funding shortages in June.\n\nThe U.N. says at least $674 million is needed to support South Sudanese refugees in Uganda this year, although only a fifth of that amount has been received.\n\nThe money is needed to provide basic services, including stocking clinics with medicines and putting up schools. Aid agencies say classroom sizes in the few available schools often exceed 200 pupils, and other children have dropped out because the nearest schools are located miles away.\n\n\"The funding shortfall in Uganda is now significantly impacting the abilities to deliver life-saving aid and key basic services,\" the UNHCR statement said.\n\nFighting persists in parts of South Sudan despite multiple cease-fire agreements. Rebel forces said Tuesday they had reclaimed their stronghold of Pagak in the northeast, less than a week after being pushed out by government forces.\n\nBoth sides have committed serious rights {"timeCrawl": "17:49:00", "uri": "709900592", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T17:49:00Z", "sim": 0.9058823585510254, "source": {"title": "Mail Online", "uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "id": "214"}, "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4793370/index.html", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368741", "body": "UN High Commissioner for Refugees Filippo Grandi talks to journalists on August 15, 2017, as he visits the Al-Nimir camp in the Sudanese state of East Darfur for an on-the-ground assessment of the situation of South Sudanese refugees living in Sudan\n\nThe UN's refugee chief said Tuesday a long period of exile lies ahead for South Sudanese refugees fleeing a war that erupted in their country after it split from the north.\n\nTens of thousands of South Sudanese have been killed and millions displaced since the world's youngest country fell into a civil war less than three years after it seceded in 2011.\n\nUrging crowds of refugees at Al-Nimir camp in the Sudanese state of East Darfur to \"be strong and hopeful\", Filippo Grandi said it was about time leaders of South Sudan ended a war that continued to rage on.\n\n\"I must confess that it may be a long term exile\" for the refugees who continue to flee from their country every day, Grandi told AFP as he toured the camp, where about 5,000 South Sudanese have taken refuge.\n\nGrandi said the refugees had to remain hopeful of returning to their country, but a lot depended on when South Sudan becomes stable.\n\n\"That hope depends on the action first and foremost of the leadership of South Sudan and the opposition,\" he said.\n\n\"They have to start behaving responsibly and thinking of their own people and not only of themselves.\"\n\nSouth Sudan's civil war began in December 2013 when President Salva Kiir accused his former deputy, Riek Machar, of plotting a coup. Since then the war has spread across the country, sweeping up other ethnic groups and local grievances.\n\nOverall the refugee population from South Sudan has reached to about two million, of which more than 430,000 have taken refuge in Sudan, the United Nations says.\n\nGrandi praised Khartoum for opening several \"human corridors\" to deliver aid directly from Sudan to areas of South Sudan, and for hosting hundreds of thousands of refugees.\n\nHowever, he said it was time to develop \"new models\" for aiding refugees, rather than just keeping them in camps.\n\n\"For how long can you support these camps?\" he said as the United Nations and other aid organisations face increasing financial crunch.\n\nIt would be better to support the local economy and infrastructure, he said, as Share your opinions in a Federal News Radio survey.\n\nAn average of 1,800 South Sudanese citizens have been arriving daily in Uganda over the past 12 months, the UNHCR said in a statement. Another 1 million or more South Sudanese are sheltering in Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Congo and Central African Republic.\n\nThe number of people fleeing jumped after deadly fighting again erupted in South Sudan's capital, Juba, in July 2016.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" the statement said.\n\n\"With refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short.\"\n\nA fundraising summit hosted by Uganda in June raised only a fraction of the $2 billion that Ugandan officials have said is needed to sufficiently look after the refugees and the communities hosting them.\n\n\"This unhappy 1-million milestone must serve as a wake-up call to the international community that much more is needed from them,\" Sarah Jackson, an Amnesty International official in the region, said in a statement Thursday. \"With no resolution to the conflict in South Sudan in sight, refugees will continue to flee to {"timeCrawl": "07:18:00", "uri": "710737237", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T07:18:00Z", "sim": 0.9019607901573181, "source": {"title": "MyMcMurray", "uri": "mymcmurray.com", "id": "1171"}, "url": "http://www.mymcmurray.com/2017/08/17/1-million-south-sudan-refugees-now-in-uganda-un-says/", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "KAMPALA, Uganda - The number of South Sudanese refugees sheltering in Uganda has reached 1 million, the United Nations said Thursday, a grim milestone for what has become the world's fastest-growing refugee crisis.\n\nUgandan officials say they are overwhelmed by the flow of people fleeing South Sudan's civil war and the U.N. refugee agency urges the international community to donate more for humanitarian assistance.\n\nAn average of 1,800 South Sudanese citizens have been arriving daily in Uganda over the past 12 months, the UNHCR said in a statement. Another one million or more South Sudanese are sheltering in Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Congo and Central African Republic.\n\nThe number of people fleeing jumped after deadly fighting again erupted in South Sudan's capital, Juba, in July 2016.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" the statement said.\n\n\"With refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short.\"\n\nA fundraising summit hosted by Uganda in June raised only a fraction of the $2 billion that Ugandan officials have said is needed to sufficiently look after the refugees and the communities hosting them.\n\nMost of the refugees are women and children fleeing violence, often along ethnic lines, since the world's newest country erupted into violence in December 2013.\n\nUgandan refugee officials have repeatedly warned the influx is straining the country's ability to be generous to the refugees, who often are given small plots of land for building temporary shelters and planting crops when they arrive.\n\nThe largest of the settlements hosting refugees from South Sudan, Bidi Bidi, is roughly 230 square kilometres (88.8 sq. miles).\n\nThe World Food Program cut food rations for some refugees amid funding shortages in June.\n\nThe U.N. says at least $674 million is needed to support South Sudanese refugees in Uganda this year, although only a fifth of that amount has been received.\n\nThe money is needed to provide basic services, including stocking clinics with medicines and putting up schools. Aid agencies say classroom sizes in the few available schools often exceed 200 pupils, and other children have dropped out because the nearest schools are located miles away.\n\n\"The funding shortfall in Uganda is now significantly impacting the abilities to deliver life-saving aid and key basic services,\" the UNHCR statement said.\n\nFighting persists in parts of South Sudan despite multiple cease-fire agreements. Rebel forces said Tuesday they had reclaimed their stronghold of Pagak in the northeast, less than a week after being pushed out by government forces.\n\nBoth sides have committed serious rights violations, including murder and rape, against civilians, according to U.N. investigators.", "id": "9630833", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "1 million South Sudan refugees now in {"timeCrawl": "05:23:00", "uri": "710691884", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T05:13:00Z", "sim": 0.9019607901573181, "source": {"title": "Associated Press", "uri": "hosted.ap.org", "id": "963"}, "url": "http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/A/AF_SOUTH_SUDAN_1_MILLION_REFUGEES?SITE=ORCOO&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "KAMPALA, Uganda (AP) -- The number of South Sudanese refugees sheltering in Uganda has reached 1 million, the United Nations said Thursday, a grim milestone for what has become the world's fastest-growing refugee crisis.\n\nUgandan officials say they are overwhelmed by the flow of people fleeing South Sudan's civil war and the U.N. refugee agency urges the international community to donate more for humanitarian assistance.\n\nAn average of 1,800 South Sudanese citizens have been arriving daily in Uganda over the past 12 months, the UNHCR said in a statement. Another one million or more South Sudanese are sheltering in Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Congo and Central African Republic.\n\nThe number of people fleeing jumped after deadly fighting again erupted in South Sudan's capital, Juba, in July 2016.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" the statement said.\n\n\"With refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short.\"\n\nA fundraising summit hosted by Uganda in June raised only a fraction of the $2 billion that Ugandan officials have said is needed to sufficiently look after the refugees and the communities hosting them.\n\nMost of the refugees are women and children fleeing violence, often along ethnic lines, since the world's newest country erupted into violence in December 2013.\n\nUgandan refugee officials have repeatedly warned the influx is straining the country's ability to be generous to the refugees, who often are given small plots of land for building temporary shelters and planting crops when they arrive.\n\nThe largest of the settlements hosting refugees from South Sudan, Bidi Bidi, is roughly 230 square kilometers (88.8 sq. miles).\n\nThe World Food Program cut food rations for some refugees amid funding shortages in June.\n\nThe U.N. says at least $674 million is needed to support South Sudanese refugees in Uganda this year, although only a fifth of that amount has been received.\n\nThe money is needed to provide basic services, including stocking clinics with medicines and putting up schools. Aid agencies say classroom sizes in the few available schools often exceed 200 pupils, and other children have dropped out because the nearest schools are located miles away.\n\n\"The funding shortfall in Uganda is now significantly impacting the abilities to deliver life-saving aid and key basic services,\" the UNHCR statement said.\n\nFighting persists in parts of South Sudan despite multiple cease-fire agreements. Rebel forces said Tuesday they had reclaimed their stronghold of Pagak in the northeast, less than a week after being pushed out by government forces.\n\nBoth sides have committed serious rights violations, including murder and rape, against civilians, according to U.N. investigators.", "id": "9615846", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "1 million South Sudan refugees now in {"timeCrawl": "05:21:00", "uri": "710691130", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T05:21:00Z", "sim": 0.9019607901573181, "source": {"title": "Metro Toronto", "uri": "metronews.ca", "id": "391"}, "url": "http://www.metronews.ca/news/world/2017/08/17/1-million-south-sudan-refugees-now-in-uganda-un-says.html", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "KAMPALA, Uganda -- The number of South Sudanese refugees sheltering in Uganda has reached 1 million, the United Nations said Thursday, a grim milestone for what has become the world's fastest-growing refugee crisis.\n\nUgandan officials say they are overwhelmed by the flow of people fleeing South Sudan's civil war and the U.N. refugee agency urges the international community to donate more for humanitarian assistance.\n\nAn average of 1,800 South Sudanese citizens have been arriving daily in Uganda over the past 12 months, the UNHCR said in a statement. Another one million or more South Sudanese are sheltering in Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Congo and Central African Republic.\n\nThe number of people fleeing jumped after deadly fighting again erupted in South Sudan's capital, Juba, in July 2016.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" the statement said.\n\n\"With refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short.\"\n\nA fundraising summit hosted by Uganda in June raised only a fraction of the $2 billion that Ugandan officials have said is needed to sufficiently look after the refugees and the communities hosting them.\n\nMost of the refugees are women and children fleeing violence, often along ethnic lines, since the world's newest country erupted into violence in December 2013.\n\nUgandan refugee officials have repeatedly warned the influx is straining the country's ability to be generous to the refugees, who often are given small plots of land for building temporary shelters and planting crops when they arrive.\n\nThe largest of the settlements hosting refugees from South Sudan, Bidi Bidi, is roughly 230 square kilometres (88.8 sq. miles).\n\nThe World Food Program cut food rations for some refugees amid funding shortages in June.\n\nThe U.N. says at least $674 million is needed to support South Sudanese refugees in Uganda this year, although only a fifth of that amount has been received.\n\nThe money is needed to provide basic services, including stocking clinics with medicines and putting up schools. Aid agencies say classroom sizes in the few available schools often exceed 200 pupils, and other children have dropped out because the nearest schools are located miles away.\n\n\"The funding shortfall in Uganda is now significantly impacting the abilities to deliver life-saving aid and key basic services,\" the UNHCR statement said.\n\nFighting persists in parts of South Sudan despite multiple cease-fire agreements. Rebel forces said Tuesday they had reclaimed their stronghold of Pagak in the northeast, less than a week after being pushed out by government forces.\n\nBoth sides have committed serious rights Another 1 million or more South Sudanese are sheltering in Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Congo and Central African Republic.\n\nThe number of people fleeing jumped after deadly fighting again erupted in South Sudan's capital, Juba, in July 2016.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" the statement said.\n\n\"With refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short.\"\n\nA fundraising summit hosted by Uganda in June raised only a fraction of the $2 billion that Ugandan officials have said is needed to sufficiently look after the refugees and the communities hosting them.\n\n\"This unhappy 1-million milestone must serve as a wake-up call to the international community that much more is needed from them,\" Sarah Jackson, an Amnesty International official in the region, said in a statement Thursday. \"With no resolution to the conflict in South Sudan in sight, refugees will continue to flee to Uganda and the humanitarian crisis will only escalate.\"\n\nMost of the refugees are women and children fleeing violence, often along ethnic lines, since the world's newest country erupted into {"timeCrawl": "05:27:00", "uri": "710694381", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T05:27:00Z", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "source": {"title": "WBOC TV 16", "uri": "wboc.com", "id": "19270"}, "url": "http://www.wboc.com/story/36154555/1-million-south-sudan-refugees-now-in-uganda-un-says", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "KAMPALA, Uganda (AP) - The number of South Sudanese refugees sheltering in Uganda has reached 1 million, the United Nations said Thursday, a grim milestone for what has become the world's fastest-growing refugee crisis.\n\nUgandan officials say they are overwhelmed by the flow of people fleeing South Sudan's civil war and the U.N. refugee agency urges the international community to donate more for humanitarian assistance.\n\nAn average of 1,800 South Sudanese citizens have been arriving daily in Uganda over the past 12 months, the UNHCR said in a statement. Another one million or more South Sudanese are sheltering in Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Congo and Central African Republic.\n\nThe number of people fleeing jumped after deadly fighting again erupted in South Sudan's capital, Juba, in July 2016.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" the statement said.\n\n\"With refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short.\"\n\nA fundraising summit hosted by Uganda in June raised only a fraction of the $2 billion that Ugandan officials have said is needed to sufficiently look after the refugees and the communities hosting them.\n\nMost of the refugees are women and children fleeing violence, often along ethnic lines, since the world's newest country erupted into violence in December 2013.\n\nUgandan refugee officials have repeatedly warned the influx is straining the country's ability to be generous to the refugees, who often are given small plots of land for building temporary shelters and planting crops when they arrive.\n\nThe largest of the settlements hosting refugees from South Sudan, Bidi Bidi, is roughly 230 square kilometers (88.8 sq. miles).\n\nThe World Food Program cut food rations for some refugees amid funding shortages in June.\n\nThe U.N. says at least $674 million is needed to support South Sudanese refugees in Uganda this year, although only a fifth of that amount has been received.\n\nThe money is needed to provide basic services, including stocking clinics with medicines and putting up schools. Aid agencies say classroom sizes in the few available schools often exceed 200 pupils, and other children have dropped out because the nearest schools are located miles away.\n\n\"The funding shortfall in Uganda is now significantly impacting the abilities to deliver life-saving aid and key basic services,\" the UNHCR statement said.\n\nFighting persists in parts of South Sudan despite multiple cease-fire agreements. Rebel forces said Tuesday they had reclaimed their stronghold of Pagak in the northeast, less than a week after being pushed out by government forces.\n\nBoth sides have committed serious rights violations, including murder and rape, against civilians, according to U.N. investigators.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"timeCrawl": "10:02:00", "uri": "710807865", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T10:02:00Z", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "source": {"title": "Belfast Telegraph", "uri": "belfasttelegraph.co.uk", "id": "226"}, "url": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/world-news/one-million-south-sudan-refugees-now-in-uganda-says-un-36041349.html", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/world-news/article36041348.ece/858c7/AUTOCROP/h342/PANews%20BT_P-7f083187-0cfc-41e2-baa1-d5de1f82a19a_I1.jpg\n\nThe number of South Sudanese refugees sheltering in Uganda has reached one million, the United Nations said, in a grim milestone for what has become the world's fastest-growing refugee crisis.\n\nUgandan officials said they are overwhelmed by the flow of people fleeing South Sudan's civil war and the UN refugee agency urged the international community to donate more for humanitarian assistance.\n\nAn average of 1,800 South Sudanese citizens have been arriving daily in Uganda over the past 12 months, the UNHCR said in a statement.\n\nAnother one million or more South Sudanese are sheltering in Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Congo and Central African Republic.\n\nThe number of people fleeing jumped after deadly fighting again erupted in South Sudan's capital Juba in July 2016.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" the statement said.\n\n\"With refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short.\"\n\nA fundraising summit hosted by Uganda in June raised only a fraction of the two billion dollars (\u00a31.5 billion) that Ugandan officials have said is needed to sufficiently look after the refugees and the communities hosting them.\n\n\"This unhappy 1-million milestone must serve as a wake-up call to the international community that much more is needed from them,\" Sarah Jackson, an Amnesty International official in the region, said in a statement.\n\n\"With no resolution to the conflict in South Sudan in sight, refugees will continue to flee to Uganda and the humanitarian crisis will only escalate.\"\n\nMost of the refugees are women and children fleeing violence, often along ethnic lines, since the world's newest country erupted into violence in December 2013.\n\nUgandan refugee officials have repeatedly warned the influx is straining the country's ability to be generous to the refugees, who are often given small plots of land for building temporary shelters and planting crops when they arrive.\n\nThe largest of the settlements hosting refugees from South Sudan, Bidi Bidi, is roughly 230 square kilometres (88.8 square miles).\n\nThe World Food Programme cut food rations for some refugees amid funding shortages in June.\n\nThe UN says at least 674 million dollars (\u00a3523 million) is needed to support South Sudanese refugees in Uganda this year, although only a fifth of that amount has been received.\n\nThe money is needed to provide basic services, including stocking clinics with medicines and putting up schools.\n\nAid agencies say classroom sizes in the few available schools often exceed 200 pupils, and other children have dropped out because the nearest schools are located miles away.\n\n\"The funding shortfall in Uganda is now significantly impacting the abilities to deliver life-saving aid and key basic services,\" the UNHCR statement said.\n\nFighting persists in parts of South Sudan despite multiple ceasefire agreements.\n\nRebel forces said on Tuesday they had reclaimed their stronghold of Pagak in the north east, less than a week after being pushed out by government forces.\n\nBoth sides have committed serious rights violations, including murder and rape, against civilians, according to UN investigators.", "id": "9658405", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "One million South Sudan refugees now in Uganda, says UN", "image": Another one million or more South Sudanese are sheltering in Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, the Congo, and the Central African Republic.\n\nThe number of people fleeing jumped after deadly fighting again erupted in South Sudan's capital, Juba, in July 2016.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls, and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" the statement said.\n\n\"With refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short.\"\n\nA fundraising summit hosted by Uganda in June raised only a fraction of the $2 billion that Ugandan officials have said is needed to sufficiently look after the refugees and the communities hosting them.\n\nMost of the refugees are women and children fleeing violence, often along ethnic lines, since the world's newest country erupted into violence in December 2013.\n\nUgandan refugee officials have repeatedly warned the influx is straining the country's ability to be generous to the refugees, who often are given small plots of land for building temporary shelters and planting crops when they arrive.\n\nThe largest of the settlements hosting refugees from South Sudan, Bidi Bidi, is roughly 230 square kilometers.\n\nThe World Food Program cut food rations for some refugees amid funding shortages in June.\n\nThe UN says at least $674 million is needed to support South Sudanese refugees in Uganda this year, although only a fifth of that amount has been received.\n\nThe money is needed to provide basic services, including stocking clinics with medicines and putting up schools. {"timeCrawl": "08:29:00", "uri": "711333182", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T08:29:00Z", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "source": {"title": "ArkansasOnline", "uri": "arkansasonline.com", "id": "766"}, "url": "http://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2017/aug/18/s-sudan-refugees-hit-1-million-in-ugand/", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "KAMPALA, Uganda -- The number of South Sudanese refugees arriving in Uganda has reached 1 million, the United Nations said Thursday, in what has become the world's fastest-growing refugee crisis.\n\nUgandan officials said they are overwhelmed by the flow of people fleeing South Sudan's civil war, and the U.N. refugee agency urged the international community to donate more for humanitarian assistance.\n\nAn average of 1,800 South Sudanese citizens have been arriving daily in Uganda over the past 12 months, the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees said in a statement. Another 1 million or more South Sudanese are taking shelter in Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Congo and Central African Republic.\n\nThe number of people fleeing jumped after deadly fighting again broke out in South Sudan's capital, Juba, in July 2016.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" the statement said.\n\n\"With refugees still arriving in the thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short,\" it added.\n\nA fundraising summit hosted by Uganda in June raised only a fraction of the $2 billion that Ugandan officials have said is needed to sufficiently look after the refugees and the communities hosting them.\n\n\"This unhappy 1-million milestone must serve as a wake-up call to the international community that much more is needed from them,\" Sarah Jackson, an Amnesty International official in the region, said in a statement Thursday.\n\n\"With no resolution to the conflict in South Sudan in sight, refugees will continue to flee to Uganda and the humanitarian crisis will only escalate.\"\n\nMost of the refugees are women and children fleeing violence, often along ethnic lines, since the world's newest country relapsed into violence in December 2013.\n\nUgandan refugee officials have repeatedly warned the influx is straining the country's ability to be generous to the refugees, who often are given small plots of land for building temporary shelters and planting crops when they arrive.\n\nThe largest of the settlements hosting refugees from South Sudan, Bidi Bidi, is roughly 88.8 square miles.\n\nThe World Food Program cut food rations for some refugees because of funding shortages in June.\n\nThe U.N. said at least $674 million is needed to support South Sudanese refugees in Uganda this year, although only a fifth of that amount has been received.\n\nThe money is needed to provide basic services, including stocking clinics with medicines and putting up schools.\n\nAid agencies said classroom sizes in the few available schools often exceed 200 pupils, and other children have dropped out because the nearest schools are miles away.\n\n\"The funding shortfall in Uganda is now significantly impacting the abilities to deliver life-saving aid and key basic services,\" the U.N. refugee agency statement said.\n\nFighting persists in parts of South Sudan despite multiple cease-fire agreements. Rebel forces said Tuesday that they had reclaimed their stronghold of Pagak in the northeast, less than a week after being pushed out by government forces.\n\nBoth sides have committed human-rights violations, including murder and rape, against civilians, according to U.N. investigators.", "id": "9851779", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-18", "title": "S. Since then the war has spread across the country, sweeping up other ethnic groups and local grievances.\n\nOverall the refugee population from South Sudan has reached to about two million, of which more than 430,000 have taken refuge in Sudan, the United Nations says.\n\nGrandi praised Khartoum for opening several \"human corridors\" to deliver aid directly from Sudan to areas of South Sudan, and for hosting hundreds of thousands of refugees.\n\nHowever, he said it was time to develop \"new models\" for aiding refugees, rather than just keeping them in camps.\n\n\"For how long can you support these camps?\" he said as the United Nations and other aid organisations face increasing financial crunch.\n\nIt would be better to support the local economy and infrastructure, he said, as {"timeCrawl": "06:20:00", "uri": "710711268", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T06:20:00Z", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "source": {"title": "Daily News and Analysis (DNA) India", "uri": "dnaindia.com", "id": "492"}, "url": "http://www.dnaindia.com/world/report-1-million-south-sudan-refugees-now-in-uganda-un-says-2532619", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "The number of South Sudanese refugees sheltering in Uganda has reached 1 million, the United Nations said today, a grim milestone for what has become the world's fastest-growing refugee crisis.\n\nUgandan officials say they are overwhelmed by the flow of people fleeing South Sudan's civil war and the UN refugee agency urges the international community to donate more for humanitarian assistance.\n\nAn average of 1,800 South Sudanese citizens have been arriving daily in Uganda over the past 12 months, the UNHCR said in a statement. Another one million or more South Sudanese are sheltering in Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Congo and Central African Republic.\n\nThe number of people fleeing jumped after deadly fighting again erupted in South Sudan's capital, Juba, in July 2016.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" the statement said.\n\n\"With refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short.\"\n\nA fundraising summit hosted by Uganda in June raised only a fraction of the USD 2 billion that Ugandan officials have said is needed to sufficiently look after the refugees and the communities hosting them.\n\nMost of the refugees are women and children fleeing violence, often along ethnic lines, since the world's newest country erupted into violence in December 2013.\n\nUgandan refugee officials have repeatedly warned the influx is straining the country's ability to be generous to the refugees, who often are given small plots of land for building temporary shelters and planting crops when they arrive.\n\nThe largest of the settlements hosting refugees from South Sudan, Bidi Bidi, is roughly 230 square kilometres.\n\nThe World Food Program cut food rations for some refugees amid funding shortages in June.\n\nThe UN says at least USD 674 million is needed to support South Sudanese refugees in Uganda this year, although only a fifth of that amount has been received.\n\nThe money is needed to provide basic services, including stocking clinics with medicines and putting up schools. Aid agencies say classroom sizes in the few available schools often exceed 200 pupils, and other children have dropped out because the nearest schools are located miles away.\n\n\"The funding shortfall in Uganda is now significantly impacting the abilities to deliver life-saving aid and key basic services,\" the UNHCR statement said.\n\nFighting persists in parts of South Sudan despite multiple cease-fire agreements. Rebel forces said Tuesday they had reclaimed their stronghold of Pagak in the northeast, less than a week after being pushed out by government forces.\n\nBoth sides have committed serious rights violations, including murder and rape, against civilians, according to UN investigators.\n\n(This article has not been edited by DNA's editorial team and is auto-generated from an agency feed.)", Another one million or more South Sudanese are sheltering in Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Congo and Central African Republic.\n\nThe number of people fleeing jumped after deadly fighting erupted in South Sudan's capital, Juba, in July 2016.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" the statement said.\n\n\"With refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short.\"\n\nA fundraising summit hosted by Uganda in June raised only a fraction of the $ 2 billion that the Ugandan officials said is needed to look after the refugees and the communities hosting them.\n\nMost of the refugees are women and children fleeing violence, often along ethnic lines, since the world's newest country erupted into violence in December 2013.\n\nUgandan refugee officials have repeatedly warned the influx is straining the country's ability to be generous to the refugees, who often are given small plots of land for building temporary shelters and to plant crops\n\nThe largest of the settlements hosting refugees from South Sudan, Bidi Bidi, is roughly 230 square kilometres.\n\nThe World Food Program cut food rations for some refugees amid funding shortages in June.\n\nThe UN says at least $ 674 million is needed to support South Sudanese refugees in Uganda this year, although only a fifth of that amount has been received.\n\nThe money is needed to provide basic services, including stocking clinics with medicines and putting up schools. {"timeCrawl": "15:57:00", "uri": "710978758", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T15:57:00Z", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "source": {"title": "WHBQ", "uri": "fox13memphis.com", "id": "114"}, "url": "http://www.fox13memphis.com/news/1-million-south-sudan-refugees-now-in-uganda-un-says/594033110", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "Ugandan officials say they are overwhelmed by the flow of people fleeing South Sudan's civil war and the U.N. refugee agency urges the international community to donate more for humanitarian assistance.\n\nAn average of 1,800 South Sudanese citizens have been arriving daily in Uganda over the past 12 months, the UNHCR said in a statement. Another 1 million or more South Sudanese are sheltering in Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Congo and Central African Republic.\n\nThe number of people fleeing jumped after deadly fighting again erupted in South Sudan's capital, Juba, in July 2016.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" the statement said.\n\n\"With refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short.\"\n\nA fundraising summit hosted by Uganda in June raised only a fraction of the $2 billion that Ugandan officials have said is needed to sufficiently look after the refugees and the communities hosting them.\n\n\"This unhappy 1-million milestone must serve as a wake-up call to the international community that much more is needed from them,\" Sarah Jackson, an Amnesty International official in the region, said in a statement Thursday. \"With no resolution to the conflict in South Sudan in sight, refugees will continue to flee to Uganda and the humanitarian crisis will only escalate.\"\n\nMost of the refugees are women and children fleeing violence, often along ethnic lines, since the world's newest country erupted into violence in December 2013.\n\nUgandan refugee officials have repeatedly warned the influx is straining the country's ability to be generous to the refugees, who often are given small plots of land for building temporary shelters and planting crops when they arrive.\n\nThe largest of the settlements hosting refugees from South Sudan, Bidi Bidi, is roughly 230 square kilometers (88.8 sq. miles).\n\nThe World Food Program cut food rations for some refugees amid funding shortages in June.\n\nThe U.N. says at least $674 million is needed to support South Sudanese refugees in Uganda this year, although only a fifth of that amount has been received.\n\nThe money is needed to provide basic services, including stocking clinics with medicines and putting up schools. Aid agencies say classroom sizes in the few available schools often exceed 200 pupils, and other children have dropped out because the nearest schools are located miles away.\n\n\"The funding shortfall in Uganda is now significantly impacting the abilities to deliver life-saving aid and key basic services,\" the UNHCR statement said.\n\nFighting persists in parts of South Sudan despite multiple cease-fire agreements. Rebel forces said Tuesday they had reclaimed their stronghold of Pagak in the northeast, less than a week after being pushed out by government forces.\n\nBoth sides have committed serious rights violations, including murder and rape, against civilians, according to U.N. investigators.", "id": "9727088", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "1 million South Sudan refugees now in
