{"timeCrawl": "07:53:00", "uri": "711319237", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T07:36:00Z", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "source": {"title": "sudantribune.com", "uri": "sudantribune.com", "id": "5454"}, "url": "http://sudantribune.com/spip.php?article63281", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368741", "body": "August 17, 2017 (KHARTOUM) - UN High Commissioner for Refugees, Filippo Grandi, called for more international support to Sudan in its humanitarian efforts to shelter South Sudanese refugees fleeing the four-year conflict in South Sudan.\n\nGrandi, the new chief of UN refugee agency, paid his first official visit as High Commissioner to Sudan this week, visited Al-Nimir refugee camp in East Darfur which hosts over 5,000 South Sudanese refugees. He also met with President Omer al-Bashir and foreign minister Ibrahim Ghanour.\n\n\"For decades, Sudan has kept its doors open to people fleeing war, hunger and hardship. I saw this myself when I worked there as a UNHCR field officer nearly 30 years ago and this continues today as South Sudanese refugees flee the horrors of war,\" Grandi said on Wednesday according to a statement released by the UNHCR on Thursday.\n\nHe further said this exceptional generosity needed to be acknowledged and supported. \"Sudan's generosity must be matched with international solidarity and resources. Much more donor support is required - and urgently - so that we can help the hundreds of thousands of refugees in the country and the communities that are hosting them.\"\n\nIn a meeting with the UNHCR representative for Sudan Noriko Yoshida on Monday 14 August, Sudan's Minister of International Cooperation Idris Suleiman discussed ways to provide the east African country with the needed funds to cover the requirements of the refugees in Sudan.\n\nSudan hosts over 416,000 South Sudanese refugees who arrived since 2013, 110,000 Eritrean refugees, and more than 100,000 Syrian refugees. Besides some 500,000 South Sudanese who stayed in Sudan following the separation are also in need of humanitarian assistance according to the UN.\n\nAccording to the UNHCR, President al-Bashir {"timeCrawl": "18:43:00", "uri": "709923400", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T18:43:00Z", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "source": {"title": "The Citizen", "uri": "citizen.co.za", "id": "4613"}, "url": "http://citizen.co.za/news/news-africa/1613782/sudan-refugees-ssudan-un/", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368741", "body": "Tens of thousands of South Sudanese have been killed and millions displaced since the world's youngest country fell into a civil war less than three years after it seceded in 2011.\n\nUrging crowds of refugees at Al-Nimir camp in the Sudanese state of East Darfur to \"be strong and hopeful\", Filippo Grandi said it was about time leaders of South Sudan ended a war that continued to rage on.\n\n\"I must confess that it may be a long term exile\" for the refugees who continue to flee from their country every day, Grandi told AFP as he toured the camp, where about 5,000 South Sudanese have taken refuge.\n\nGrandi said the refugees had to remain hopeful of returning to their country, but a lot depended on when South Sudan becomes stable.\n\n\"That hope depends on the action first and foremost of the leadership of South Sudan and the opposition,\" he said.\n\n\"They have to start behaving responsibly and thinking of their own people and not only of themselves.\"\n\nSouth Sudan's civil war began in December 2013 when President Salva Kiir accused his former deputy, Riek Machar, of plotting a coup. Since then the war has spread across the country, sweeping up other ethnic groups and local grievances.\n\nOverall the refugee population from South Sudan has reached to about two million, of which more than 430,000 have taken refuge in Sudan, the United Nations says.\n\nGrandi praised Khartoum for opening several \"human corridors\" to deliver aid directly from Sudan to areas of South Sudan, and for hosting hundreds of thousands of refugees.\n\nHowever, he said it was time to develop \"new models\" for aiding refugees, rather than just keeping them in camps.\n\n\"For how long can you support these camps?\" he said as the United Nations and other aid organisations face increasing financial crunch.\n\nIt would be better to support the local economy and infrastructure, he said, as {"timeCrawl": "01:59:00", "uri": "710634160", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T01:59:00Z", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "source": {"title": "The Sudanese Media Centre", "uri": "smc.sd", "id": "7528"}, "url": "http://smc.sd/en/urgency-needed-quest-south-sudan-peace-un-refugee-chief/", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368741", "body": "During a visit to Sudan, Filippo Grandi calls on warring parties, regional states and the international community to do more to end the conflict which has uprooted nearly four million people.\n\nAL-NAMIR, East Darfur, Sudan - As worsening violence in South Sudan drives ever more men, women and children to run for their lives, the UN Refugee Chief is calling on warring parties, regional states and the international community to look for urgent ways to find peace.\n\nUN High Commissioner for Refugees Filippo Grandi made the call during a visit to Al-Nimir refugee camp in East Darfur, Sudan, where he met South Sudanese refugees and their local hosts.\n\n\"My coming here has one reason - just as I did in Uganda, Ethiopia and from Juba itself, to appeal to the leadership of South Sudan, to the opposition of South Sudan, to the States in the region and to the international community at large, to inject some sense of urgency in the quest of peace in South Sudan itself,\" Grandi said during the visit this week.\n\nHis call comes as conflict and drought have displaced nearly four million South Sudanese both inside the country and beyond its borders since violence erupted there in 2013. Efforts to restore peace have so far proven unsuccessful.\n\n\"The victims of this failure, so far, are the civilians. The civilians that we see around here.\"\n\n\"The victims of this failure, so far, are the civilians. The civilians that we see around here. People that have left everything behind. Often women and children, without their men, to embark on an uncertain life because they are too afraid to stay back home in their villages which are affected by war,\" Grandi said.\n\nDuring his visit to Sudan, the UN Refugee Chief also highlighted the country's key role in hosting hundreds of thousands of South Sudanese refugees. Al-Nimir camp hosts more than 5,000 refugees - over 90 per cent of them women and children.\n\n\"I want to say to the world that Sudan is keeping its doors open at a time when so many countries are closing doors,\" Grandi said,\n\nThe High Commissioner also appealed for more help for Sudan. \"Often, we forget that Sudan continues to be a very key host country not just for South Sudanese but for Eritreans, Syrians and many other refugees,\" he said.\n\nUN Refugee Chief visits South Sudanese Refugees in Sudan\n\nGrandi praised the model of cooperation and coexistence between refugees and the local communities in Sudan.\n\n\"Throughout the world, we are experimenting with new ways to promote livelihoods, to promote new sources of energy and other forms of sustainable development for refugees and for the communities hosting them. I think that Sudan qualifies very much for this model of development.\"\n\nDuring his visit to the camp, Grandi met Sadia Mohammed Wali, a 42 year-old refugee mother. Sadia fled South Sudan with her seven children when fighting erupted in her home town back in June this year.\n\n\"We came with our children and we had nothing to feed them.\"\n\n\"We were very scared,\" she said giving details of her month-long trip to reach safety in Sudan. \"The journey was so difficult for us, because we came with our children and we had nothing to feed them. We were moving in huge groups,\" she said. \"Those who carried some small foods would share and we gave them to the children.\"\n\nShe expressed her desire for her children to get a good education and get some help herself to support her small business, selling roasted peanuts, dumplings and sweets.\n\nSudan hosts some 416,000 refugees from South Sudan since 2013 - including some 170,000 new arrivals so far this year.\n\nSouth Sudan became the world's youngest country when it gained independence from Sudan in 2011..\n\nHundreds of thousands of other refugees - who stayed in Sudan following the partition are also in need of humanitarian assistance.\n\nOn Wednesday, the UN Refugee Chief concluded his visit by meeting with Sudan's leaders and authorities in Khartoum.\n\nSource: {"timeCrawl": "11:17:00", "uri": "710842690", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T11:17:00Z", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "source": {"title": "UNHCR", "uri": "unhcr.org", "id": "6424"}, "url": "http://www.unhcr.org/news/press/2017/8/599567fc4/un-refugee-chief-urges-international-recognition-support-sudan.html", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368741", "body": "UN High Commissioner for Refugees, Filippo Grandi, paid his first official visit as High Commissioner to Sudan this week, at a time when refugees continue to flee the brutal conflict in South Sudan. He called on the international community to recognize Sudan's long-standing tradition of hosting refugees and asked for more support for the country.\n\n\"For decades, Sudan has kept its doors open to people fleeing war, hunger and hardship. I saw this myself when I worked there as a UNHCR field officer nearly 30 years ago and this continues today as South Sudanese refugees flee the horrors of war,\" UNHCR's Grandi said on Wednesday while wrapping-up his visit to Sudan.\n\nSudan is one of the major hosting countries for refugees fleeing the deadly conflict in South Sudan. These refugees are able to benefit from the government's extension of certain freedoms, including to work and move, and also receive generous support from host communities.\n\nThe UN Refugee Chief visited Al-Nimir refugee camp in East Darfur during his visit, hosting over 5,000 South Sudanese refugees who arrived at the camp in April, and praised the solidarity of the local Sudanese hosts. \"Host communities are generously sharing all available resources, but they are very visibly under immense pressure with already scarce resources.\"\n\nGrandi said this exceptional generosity needed to be acknowledged and supported. \"Sudan's generosity must be matched with international solidarity and resources. Much more donor support is required - and urgently - so that we can help the hundreds of thousands of refugees in the country and the communities that are hosting them.\"\n\nThe UN refugee chief also called once again on the international community to do much more to end the fighting in South Sudan, which is causing the world's fastest growing forced displacement tragedy, without an immediate end in sight. \"Parties to the conflict, regional states and the international community need to put an end to this tragedy,\" he said.\n\nHigh Commissioner Grandi met Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir and welcomed the President's assurances that Sudan will continue providing safety to those fleeing conflict and persecution - including those who arrive from South Sudan, and other countries in the region.\n\nSudan has hosted over 416,000 South Sudanese refugees since 2013 - including some 170,000 new arrivals in 2017, making it one of the largest refugee receiving countries in the region. Hundreds of thousands of other South Sudanese who stayed in Sudan following the separation of the two countries are also in need of humanitarian assistance. {"timeCrawl": "14:34:00", "uri": "710372163", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T14:34:00Z", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "source": {"title": "UNHCR", "uri": "unhcr.org", "id": "6424"}, "url": "http://www.unhcr.org/news/latest/2017/8/59944e204/urgency-needed-quest-south-sudan-peace-un-refugee-chief.html", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368741", "body": "AL-NAMIR, East Darfur, Sudan - As worsening violence in South Sudan drives ever more men, women and children to run for their lives, the UN Refugee Chief is calling on warring parties, regional states and the international community to look for urgent ways to find peace.\n\nUN High Commissioner for Refugees Filippo Grandi made the call during a visit to Al-Nimir refugee camp in East Darfur, Sudan, where he met South Sudanese refugees and their local hosts.\n\n\"My coming here has one reason - just as I did in Uganda, Ethiopia and from Juba itself, to appeal to the leadership of South Sudan, to the opposition of South Sudan, to the States in the region and to the international community at large, to inject some sense of urgency in the quest of peace in South Sudan itself,\" Grandi said during the visit this week.\n\nHis call comes as conflict and drought have displaced nearly four million South Sudanese both inside the country and beyond its borders since violence erupted there in 2013. Efforts to restore peace have so far proven unsuccessful.\n\n\"The victims of this failure, so far, are the civilians. The civilians that we see around here.\"\n\n\"The victims of this failure, so far, are the civilians. The civilians that we see around here. People that have left everything behind. Often women and children, without their men, to embark on an uncertain life because they are too afraid to stay back home in their villages which are affected by war,\" Grandi said.\n\nDuring his visit to Sudan, the UN Refugee Chief also highlighted the country's key role in hosting hundreds of thousands of South Sudanese refugees. Al-Nimir camp hosts more than 5,000 refugees - over 90 per cent of them women and children.\n\n\"I want to say to the world that Sudan is keeping its doors open at a time when so many countries are closing doors,\" Grandi said,\n\nThe High Commissioner also appealed for more help for Sudan. \"Often, we forget that Sudan continues to be a very key host country not just for South Sudanese but for Eritreans, Syrians and many other refugees,\" he said.\n\nGrandi praised the model of cooperation and coexistence between refugees and the local communities in Sudan.\n\n\"Throughout the world, we are experimenting with new ways to promote livelihoods, to promote new sources of energy and other forms of sustainable development for refugees and for the communities hosting them. I think that Sudan qualifies very much for this model of development.\"\n\nDuring his visit to the camp, Grandi met Sadia Mohammed Wali, a 42 year-old refugee mother. Sadia fled South Sudan with her seven children when fighting erupted in her home town back in June this year.\n\n\"We came with our children and we had nothing to feed them.\"\n\n\"We were very scared,\" she said giving details of her month-long trip to reach safety in Sudan. \"The journey was so difficult for us, because we came with our children and we had nothing to feed them. We were moving in huge groups,\" she said. \"Those who carried some small foods would share and we gave them to the children.\"\n\nShe expressed her desire for her children to get a good education and get some help herself to support her small business, selling roasted peanuts, dumplings and sweets.\n\nSudan hosts some 416,000 refugees from South Sudan since 2013 - including some 170,000 new arrivals so far this year.\n\nSouth Sudan became the world's youngest country when it gained independence from Sudan in 2011..\n\nHundreds of thousands of other refugees - who stayed in Sudan {"timeCrawl": "05:54:00", "uri": "711271799", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T05:54:00Z", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "source": {"title": "africa-newsroom.com", "uri": "africa-newsroom.com", "id": "7043"}, "url": "https://www.africa-newsroom.com/press/south-sudan-refugees-in-uganda-pass-1-million-mark-unhcr-renews-call-for-help", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "In Uganda, more than 85 per cent of the refugees who have arrived there are women and children (below 18 years in age)\n\nUNHCR, the UN Refugee Agency, is today reiterating its call to the international community for urgent additional support for the South Sudan refugee situation and Uganda in particular, where the number of refugees from South Sudan has now reached 1 million.\n\nOver the past 12 months, an average of 1,800 South Sudanese have been arriving in Uganda every day. In addition to the million there, a million or even more South Sudanese refugees are being hosted by Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Democratic Republic of the Congo and Central African Republic.\n\nIn Uganda, more than 85 per cent of the refugees who have arrived there are women and children (below 18 years in age). Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls, and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription.\n\nWith refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short. For Uganda, US$674 million is needed for South Sudanese refugees this year, but so far only a fifth of this amount (21 per cent) has been received. Elsewhere in the region, the picture is only marginally better - in all US$883.5 million is needed for the South Sudan situation, but only US$250 million has been received.\n\nThe funding shortfall in Uganda is now significantly impacting the abilities to deliver life-saving aid and key basic services. In June, the World Food Programme was forced to cut food rations for refugees. Across settlements in northern Uganda, health clinics are being forced to provide vital medical care with too few doctors, healthcare workers and medicines. Schooling, meanwhile is also being impacted. Class sizes often exceed 200 pupils, with some lessons held in the open air. Many refugee children are dropping out of education as the nearest schools are too far away for them to easily access.\n\nSince December 2013, when South Sudan's crisis erupted in Juba, more than two {"timeCrawl": "10:22:00", "uri": "710817464", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T10:22:00Z", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "source": {"title": "The Telegraph", "uri": "telegraph.co.uk", "id": "220"}, "url": "http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/08/17/worlds-largest-refugee-settlement-never-heard/", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "The number of South Sudanese refugees sheltering in Uganda has reached 1 million, the United Nations said Thursday, a grim milestone for what has become the world's fastest-growing refugee crisis.\n\nThe largest of the settlements hosting refugees from South Sudan is Bidi Bidi.\n\nIt is roughly 230 square kilometres (88.8 sq. miles) and houses at least 272,000 refugees - making it the largest settlement of its kind in the world.\n\nDrone footage has been released by Oxfam to highlight the scale of Uganda's refugee crisis.\n\nOxfam and its local partners are currently supporting over 280,000 refugees in four districts with emergency food, clean water, sanitation services such as toilets, activities and information to help people stay healthy and work and training to help people earn a living.\n\nUgandan officials say they are overwhelmed by the flow of people fleeing South Sudan's civil war and the U.N. refugee agency urges the international community to donate more for humanitarian assistance.\n\nAn average of 1,800 South Sudanese citizens have been arriving daily in Uganda over the past 12 months, the UNHCR said in a statement. Another 1 million or more South Sudanese are sheltering in Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Congo and Central African Republic.\n\nThe number of people fleeing jumped after deadly fighting again erupted in South Sudan's capital, Juba, in July 2016.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" the statement said.\n\n\"With refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short.\"\n\nA fundraising summit hosted by Uganda in June raised only a fraction of the $2 billion that Ugandan officials have said is needed to sufficiently look after the refugees and the communities hosting them.\n\n\"This unhappy 1-million milestone must serve as a wake-up call to the international community that much more is needed from them,\" Sarah Jackson, an Amnesty International official in the region, said in a statement Thursday. \"With no resolution to the conflict in South Sudan in sight, refugees will continue to flee to Uganda and the humanitarian crisis will only escalate.\"\n\nMost of the refugees are women and children fleeing violence, often along ethnic lines, since the world's newest country erupted into violence in December 2013.\n\nUgandan refugee officials have repeatedly warned the influx is straining the country's ability to be generous to the refugees, who often are given small plots of land for {"timeCrawl": "09:36:00", "uri": "711361998", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T09:36:00Z", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "source": {"title": "The Citizen", "uri": "citizen.co.za", "id": "4613"}, "url": "http://citizen.co.za/news/news-africa/1617436/number-of-south-sudan-refugees-in-uganda-now-more-than-1-million/", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "More than 85% of the refugees who have arrived in Uganda are women and children, below the age of 18.\n\nAs the number of refugees from South Sudan into Uganda passes one million - the vast majority being women and children - the United Nations refugee agency on Friday reiterated its call for urgent additional support.\n\n\"Over the past 12 months, an average of 1 800 South Sudanese have been arriving in Uganda every day,\" said the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) in a statement.\n\n\"In addition to the million there, a million, or even more South Sudanese refugees are being hosted by Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Democratic Republic of the Congo and Central African Republic,\" it added.\n\nMore than 85 percent of the refugees who have arrived in Uganda are women and children, below the age of 18.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls, and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" emphasised UNHCR, explaining that even as thousands of refugees arrive, aid deliveries are increasingly falling short.\n\nThe UN agency underscored that although $674 million was needed for South Sudanese refugees in Uganda this year, so far only a fifth of this amount, or 21 percent, has been received.\n\n\"Elsewhere in the region, the picture is only marginally better,\" the statement continued, saying that while a total of $883.5 million was needed for the South Sudan situation, only $250 million has been received.\n\nThe funding shortfall in Uganda is now significantly impacting the abilities to deliver life-saving aid and key basic services.\n\n\"In June, the World Food Programme was forced to cut food rations for refugees. Across settlements in northern Uganda, health clinics are being forced to provide vital medical care with too few doctors, healthcare workers and medicines,\" UNHCR elaborated.\n\nMeanwhile, schooling is also being impacted. Class sizes often exceed 200 pupils, with some lessons held in the open air. Many refugee children are dropping out of education as the nearest schools are too far away for them to easily access.\n\nSince December 2013, when South Sudan's crisis erupted in the capital Juba, more than two million South Sudanese have fled to neighbouring countries, while another two million people are estimated to be internally displaced, the statement concluded.", "id": "9863406", {"timeCrawl": "19:50:00", "uri": "711083171", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T19:40:00Z", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "source": {"title": "sudantribune.com", "uri": "sudantribune.com", "id": "5454"}, "url": "http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article63274", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "August 17, 2017 (KAMPALA) - The number of South Sudanese refugees in Uganda has now exceeded one million, the United Nations refugee agency (UNHCR) said, amid calls for urgent additional support.\n\nMajority of the refugees, the agency said, are women and children.\n\n\"Over the past 12 months, averages of 1,800 South Sudanese have been arriving in Uganda every day,\" UNHCR said in a statement.\n\n\"In addition to the million there, a million or even more South Sudanese refugees are being hosted by Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Democratic Republic of the Congo and Central African Republic,\" it added.\n\nAccording the UN agency, however, over 85% of the refugees who have arrived in Uganda are women and children below 18 years.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls, and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" said UNHCR.\n\nAs of refugees arrive, it said, aid delivery is increasingly falling short.\n\nThe UN agency underscored that although $674 million is needed for South Sudanese refugees in Uganda this year, so far only a fifth of this amount, or 21%, has so far been received.\n\nAlthough a total of $883.5 million is needed for the South Sudan situation, only $250 million, according to UNHCR, has been received.\n\nThe funding shortfall in Uganda is now significantly impacting the abilities to deliver life-saving aid and key basic services, the UN said.\n\n\"In June, the World Food Programme was forced to cut food rations for refugees. Across settlements in northern Uganda, health clinics are being forced to provide vital medical care with too few doctors, healthcare workers and medicines,\" UNHCR further explained.\n\nCALLS FOR INTERNATIONAL ASSISTANCE\n\nMeanwhile, Amnesty International has urged the international community to deliver and improve on existing financial commitments to help Uganda support the refugees it is hosting, following reports that one million South Sudanese are in the country.\n\nThe rights body, in a statement, said it documented evidence of unlawful killings, sexual violence, detention, torture, the purposeful destruction of private and public property, the use of food as a weapon of war and other serious human rights violations in South Sudan, which led to forced displacements into neighboring Uganda.\n\n\"This unhappy one-million milestone must serve as a wake-up call to the international community that much more is needed from them. With no resolution to the conflict in South Sudan in sight, refugees will continue to flee to Uganda and the humanitarian crisis will only escalate,\" said Sarah Jackson, Amnesty International's Deputy Regional Director for East Africa, the Horn and the Great Lakes.\n\n\"While the Ugandan government, the UN and NGOs have done a commendable job, they are now struggling to meet even the most basic needs of South Sudan's refugees, including food, water and shelter, let alone other needs such as psychosocial support for refugees who are deeply traumatized,\" she added.\n\nSince December 2013 when South Sudan's crisis started, more than two million South Sudanese have fled to neighbouring countries, while another two million people are estimated to be internally displaced, statistics {"timeCrawl": "19:09:00", "uri": "711064650", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T19:09:00Z", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "source": {"title": "Radio Dabanga", "uri": "dabangasudan.org", "id": "7199"}, "url": "https://www.dabangasudan.org/en/all-news/article/un-high-commissioner-concludes-sudan-visit", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368741", "body": "The Sudan Minister for Foreign Affairs, Professor Ibrahim Ghandour on Wednesday received the visiting United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Filippo Grandi, who was on a two-day visit to Sudan.\n\nThe official Sudan News Agency (SUNA) reports that the meeting reviewed the situation of refugees in Sudan and those coming from South Sudan in particular and who were visited by the high commissioner in the refugee camp of Nimir in East Darfur.\n\nThe commissioner commended the role played by the Sudan towards refugees and its support for the UN and the UNHCR programmes in particular.\n\nHe further commended the generosity of the Sudanese communities that have been hosting refugees driven by civil strives and hunger in their home areas in south Sudan and other neighbouring countries.\n\nHe said this was not something strange for the Sudanese people whom, he said, he had known while working in Eastern Sudan back in the nineteen eighties\n\nThe Commissioner said the international community holds high the assistance provided by the Sudan and its sharing of its resources with the refugees and that therefore he was of the view that the Sudan should receive more and more assistance from the international community so that it could shoulder such a huge responsibility on behalf of the international community.\n\nThe commissioner said UNHCR is of the view that the economic embargo imposed on the Sudan should be revoked, expressing his hope that this should be carried out in October a matter that would help the Sudanese government and the Sudanese people achieve the stability desired and achieve sustainable development in the country.\n\nSouth Sudanese refugees\n\nMinister Ghandour, welcomed the visit of the UNHCR commissioner to Sudan saying that it reflect the view of the international community as to the role being played by Sudan in hosting the refugees from a number of countries, and from South Sudan in particular.\n\nHe said this was also to point out that the international community should play its role in assisting the Sudan and that it was imperative to find a peaceful solution to the conflict currently going on in South Sudan\n\nThe meeting also discussed the return of Sudanese refugees in Chad and the tripartite agreement signed between the Sudan, Chad and the UN for the voluntary return of those refugees to their home areas in the Sudan, following the stability and peace achieved there.\n\nInterior Minister\n\nWhile in Sudan, Grandi also met with the Minister of interior, General Hamid Mohamed Manan, the representative of UNHCR in Khartoum, Noriko Yoshida and the commissioner of the refugee affairs, Engineer Hamad Al Juzouli.\n\nThe meeting reviewed the Sudan's effort in hosting the refugees and the asylum seekers from neighbouring countries, and its role in preparing appropriate circumstance for dignified life via providing security, shelter, the health and education assistances \"despite the weak regional and international support provided to Sudan that do not meet needs of the refugees\".\n\nThe high commissioner's visit concluded yesterday.", "id": "9759535", "details": {}, "date": {"timeCrawl": "06:13:00", "uri": "710708160", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T06:13:00Z", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "source": {"title": "WSOC", "uri": "wsoctv.com", "id": "497"}, "url": "http://www.wsoctv.com/news/national-news/ap-top-news/1-million-south-sudan-refugees-now-in-uganda-un-says/594030908", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "Ugandan officials say they are overwhelmed by the flow of people fleeing South Sudan's civil war and the U.N. refugee agency urges the international community to donate more for humanitarian assistance.\n\nAn average of 1,800 South Sudanese citizens have been arriving daily in Uganda over the past 12 months, the UNHCR said in a statement. Another one million or more South Sudanese are sheltering in Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Congo and Central African Republic.\n\nThe number of people fleeing jumped after deadly fighting again erupted in South Sudan's capital, Juba, in July 2016.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" the statement said.\n\n\"With refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short.\"\n\nA fundraising summit hosted by Uganda in June raised only a fraction of the $2 billion that Ugandan officials have said is needed to sufficiently look after the refugees and the communities hosting them.\n\nMost of the refugees are women and children fleeing violence, often along ethnic lines, since the world's newest country erupted into violence in December 2013.\n\nUgandan refugee officials have repeatedly warned the influx is straining the country's ability to be generous to the refugees, who often are given small plots of land for building temporary shelters and planting crops when they arrive.\n\nThe largest of the settlements hosting refugees from South Sudan, Bidi Bidi, is roughly 230 square kilometers (88.8 sq. miles).\n\nThe World Food Program cut food rations for some refugees amid funding shortages in June.\n\nThe U.N. says at least $674 million is needed to support South Sudanese refugees in Uganda this year, although only a fifth of that amount has been received.\n\nThe money is needed to provide basic services, including stocking clinics with medicines and putting up schools. Aid agencies say classroom sizes in the few available schools often exceed 200 pupils, and other children have dropped out because the nearest schools are located miles away.\n\n\"The funding shortfall in Uganda is now significantly impacting the abilities to deliver life-saving aid and key basic services,\" the UNHCR statement said.\n\nFighting persists in parts of South Sudan despite multiple cease-fire agreements. Rebel forces said Tuesday they had reclaimed their stronghold of Pagak in the northeast, less than a week after being pushed out by government forces.\n\nBoth sides have committed serious rights violations, including murder and rape, against civilians, according to U.N. investigators.", "id": "9621922", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "1 million South Sudan refugees now in {"timeCrawl": "05:10:00", "uri": "710117260", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T05:10:00Z", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "source": {"title": "alaraby", "uri": "alaraby.co.uk", "id": "6819"}, "url": "https://www.alaraby.co.uk/english/news/2017/8/16/south-sudan-refugees-face-long-exile-uns-grandi", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368741", "body": "Tens of thousands of South Sudanese have been killed and millions displaced [Getty]\n\nThe UN's refugee chief has said a long period of exile lies ahead for South Sudanese refugees fleeing the civil war.\n\nThe UN's refugee chief said on Tuesday a long period of exile lies ahead for South Sudanese refugees fleeing the war that erupted in their country after it split from the north.\n\nTens of thousands of South Sudanese have been killed and millions displaced since the world's youngest country fell into a civil war less than three years after it seceded in 2011.\n\nUrging crowds of refugees at al-Nimir camp in the Sudanese state of East Darfur to \"be strong and hopeful\", Filippo Grandi said it was about time leaders of South Sudan ended a war that continues to rage on.\n\n\"I must confess that I think it may be a long-term exile\" for the refugees who continue to flee from their country every day, Grandi told AFP as he toured the camp, where about 5,000 South Sudanese have taken refuge.\n\nGiven the bloodshed in South Sudan, he said, many refugees would \"think twice\" before returning to their homes.\n\nGrandi said the refugees had to remain hopeful of returning to their country, but a lot depended on when South Sudan becomes stable.\n\n\"That hope depends on the action first and foremost of the leadership of South Sudan and of the opposition,\" he said.\n\n\"They have to start behaving responsibly and thinking of their own people and not only of themselves.\"\n\nSouth Sudan's civil war began in December 2013 when President Salva Kiir accused his former deputy, Riek Machar, of plotting a coup. Since then the war has spread across the country, sweeping up ethnic groups and local grievances.\n\nOverall the refugee population from South Sudan has reached about two million, of whom more than 430,000 have taken refuge in Sudan, the United Nations says.\n\nGrandi praised Khartoum for opening \"human corridors\" to deliver aid directly from Sudan to areas of South Sudan, and for hosting hundreds of thousands of refugees.\n\n\"Sudan has kept its doors open at a time when so many countries have closed their doors,\" he said, addressing hundreds of refugees gathered to meet him in the sprawling camp of thatched huts and brick homes.\n\nGrandi said it was time to develop \"new models\" for aiding refugees, rather than just keeping them in camps.\n\n\"For how long can you support these camps?\" he said as aid agencies face increasing financial struggles.\n\nIt would be better to support the local economy, he said, as that would \"benefit the refugees also\".\n\nWhile touring the camp, Grandi visited a newly built school as well as some refugee families in their huts, where women described how they fled the war at home.\n\n\"We will now return only when there is peace in our country,\" one woman, who came to Al Nimir in May, told Grandi.\n\n\"Don't lose hope,\" Grandi told her, as behind him groups of refugees performed traditional dances to mark his visit.\n\nUrging Khartoum to continue supporting the refugees, Grandi said the occupants of camps should also \"respect the law\" of the land.\n\nEarlier this month a mob of South Sudanese refugees went on a rampage at the al-Waral camp in Sudan's southern White Nile state after reports that a refugee youth had died in police custody.\n\nThe mob burned down the camp's administrative buildings and looted warehouses, the UN refugee agency UNHCR said.\n\nKhartoum now plans to split the al-Waral camp, which has more than 50,000 South Sudanese refugees, into three separate units.\n\n\"It worries me if the law is broken, and it worries me that this may open up a feeling of hostility to the refugees,\" said Grandi when asked about the unrest.", "id": "9406496", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", {"timeCrawl": "15:09:00", "uri": "710954638", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T15:09:00Z", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "source": {"title": "UN News Service Section", "uri": "un.org", "id": "3597"}, "url": "http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=57373", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368741", "body": "17 August 2017 - The United Nations refugee chief has called for international solidarity and resources to aid Sudan, which is one of the major hosting countries for refugees fleeing the conflict in South Sudan.\n\n\"Sudan's generosity must be matched with international solidarity and resources. Much more donor support is required - and urgently - so that we can help the hundreds of thousands of refugees in the country and the communities that are hosting them,\" UN High Commissioner for Refugees, Filippo Grandi, said yesterday wrapping up his first visit as the head of UNHCR to Sudan.\n\nThe UN refugee chief also reiterated his call on the international community to do much more to end the fighting in South Sudan, which is causing the world's fastest growing forced displacement tragedy, without an immediate end in sight.\n\n\"Parties to the conflict, regional states and the international community need to put an end to this tragedy,\" he said.\n\nDuring the visit this week, Mr. Grandi met with South Sudanese refugees and their local hosts at the Al-Nimir refugee camp in East Darfur, Sudan.\n\n\"My coming here has one reason - just as I did in Uganda, Ethiopia and from Juba itself, to appeal to the leadership of South Sudan, to the opposition of South Sudan, to the States in the region and to the international community at large, to inject some sense of urgency in the quest of peace in South Sudan itself,\" Mr. Grandi said.\n\nThe High Commissioners met with Sudan's President, Omar al-Bashir, and, according to a UNHCR press release, welcomed the President's assurances that Sudan will continue providing safety to those fleeing conflict and persecution - including those who arrive from South Sudan, and other countries in the region.\n\nSudan has hosted over 416,000 South Sudanese refugees since 2013, including some 170,000 new arrivals in 2017, making it one of the largest refugee-receiving countries in the region, UNHCR reported.\n\nHundreds of thousands of other South Sudanese who stayed in Sudan following the separation of the two countries are also in need of humanitarian assistance. {"timeCrawl": "05:05:00", "uri": "710685601", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T05:05:00Z", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "source": {"title": "UNHCR", "uri": "unhcr.org", "id": "6424"}, "url": "http://www.unhcr.org/news/press/2017/8/599457a34/south-sudan-refugees-uganda-pass-1-million-mark-unhcr-renews-call-help.html", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "UNHCR, the UN Refugee Agency, is today reiterating its call to the international community for urgent additional support for the South Sudan refugee situation and Uganda in particular, where the number of refugees from South Sudan has now reached 1 million.\n\nOver the past 12 months, an average of 1,800 South Sudanese have been arriving in Uganda every day. In addition to the million there, a million or even more South Sudanese refugees are being hosted by Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Democratic Republic of the Congo and Central African Republic.\n\nIn Uganda, more than 85 per cent of the refugees who have arrived there are women and children (below 18 years in age). Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls, and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription.\n\nWith refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short. For Uganda, US$674 million is needed for South Sudanese refugees this year, but so far only a fifth of this amount (21 per cent) has been received. Elsewhere in the region, the picture is only marginally better - in all US$883.5 million is needed for the South Sudan situation, but only US$250 million has been received.\n\nThe funding shortfall in Uganda is now significantly impacting the abilities to deliver life-saving aid and key basic services. In June, the World Food Programme was forced to cut food rations for refugees. Across settlements in northern Uganda, health clinics are being forced to provide vital medical care with too few doctors, healthcare workers and medicines. Schooling, meanwhile is also being impacted. Class sizes often exceed 200 pupils, with some lessons held in the open air. Many refugee children are dropping out of education as the nearest schools are too far away for them to easily access.\n\nSince December 2013, when South Sudan's crisis erupted in Juba, more than two million South Sudanese have fled to neighbouring countries, while another two million people are estimated to be internally displaced.", "id": "9613376", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": {"timeCrawl": "14:46:00", "uri": "710377878", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T14:46:00Z", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "source": {"title": "en.farsnews.com", "uri": "en.farsnews.com", "id": "36"}, "url": "http://en.farsnews.com/newstext.aspx?nn=13960525001403", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368741", "body": "TEHRAN (FNA)- The UN's refugee chief said a long period of exile lies ahead for South Sudanese refugees fleeing the civil war.\n\nThe UN's refugee chief said a long period of exile lies ahead for South Sudanese refugees fleeing the war that erupted in their country after it split from the North, New Arab reported.\n\nTens of thousands of South Sudanese have been killed and millions displaced since the world's youngest country fell into a civil war less than three years after it seceded in 2011.\n\nUrging crowds of refugees at al-Nimir camp in the Sudanese state of East Darfur to \"be strong and hopeful\", Filippo Grandi said it was about time leaders of South Sudan ended a war that continues to rage on.\n\n\"I must confess that I think it may be a long-term exile\" for the refugees who continue to flee from their country every day, Grandi told AFP as he toured the camp, where about 5,000 South Sudanese have taken refuge.\n\nGiven the bloodshed in South Sudan, he said, many refugees would \"think twice\" before returning to their homes.\n\nGrandi said the refugees had to remain hopeful of returning to their country, but a lot depended on when South Sudan becomes stable.\n\n\"That hope depends on the action first and foremost of the leadership of South Sudan and of the opposition,\" he said.\n\n\"They have to start behaving responsibly and thinking of their own people and not only of themselves.\"\n\nSouth Sudan's civil war began in December 2013 when President Salva Kiir accused his former deputy, Riek Machar, of plotting a coup. Since then the war has spread across the country, sweeping up ethnic groups and local grievances.\n\nOverall the refugee population from South Sudan has reached about two million, of whom more than 430,000 have taken refuge in Sudan, the United Nations says.\n\nGrandi praised Khartoum for opening \"human corridors\" to deliver aid directly from Sudan to areas of South Sudan, and for hosting hundreds of thousands of refugees.\n\n\"Sudan has kept its doors open at a time when so many countries have closed their doors,\" he said, addressing hundreds of refugees gathered to meet him in the sprawling camp of thatched huts and brick homes.\n\nGrandi said it was time to develop \"new models\" for aiding refugees, rather than just keeping them in camps.\n\n\"For how long can you support these camps?\" he said as aid agencies face increasing financial struggles.\n\nIt would be better to support the local economy, he said, as that would \"benefit the refugees also\".\n\nWhile touring the camp, Grandi visited a newly built school as well as some refugee families in their huts, where women described how they fled the war at home.\n\n\"We will now return only when there is peace in our country,\" one woman, who came to Al Nimir in May, told Grandi.\n\n\"Don't lose hope,\" Grandi told her, as behind him groups of refugees performed traditional dances to mark his visit.\n\nUrging Khartoum to continue supporting the refugees, Grandi said the occupants of camps should also \"respect the law\" of the land.\n\nEarlier this month a mob of South Sudanese refugees went on a rampage at the al-Waral camp in Sudan's southern White Nile state after reports that a refugee youth had died in police custody.\n\nThe mob burned down the camp's administrative buildings and looted warehouses, the UN refugee agency UNHCR said.\n\nKhartoum now plans to split the al-Waral camp, which has more than 50,000 South Sudanese refugees, into three separate units.\n\n\"It worries me if the law is broken, and it worries me that this may open up a feeling of hostility to the refugees,\" said Grandi when asked about the unrest.", "id": "9502031", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-16", {"timeCrawl": "08:57:00", "uri": "710780560", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T08:57:00Z", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "source": {"title": "Xinhuanet.com", "uri": "news.xinhuanet.com", "id": "942"}, "url": "http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-08/17/c_136533559.htm", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "GENEVA/KAMPALA, Aug. 17 (Xinhua) -- The United Nations (UN) Refugee Agency UNHCR on Thursday announced that the number of refugees in Uganda from South Sudan has reached 1 million.\n\nThe UN agency said that over the past 12 months, an average of 1,800 South Sudanese have been arriving in Uganda each day.\n\nIn addition to the million there, UNHCR said another million or even more South Sudanese refugees are being hosted by Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, the Democratic Republic of the Congo and the Central African Republic.\n\nReiterating its call to the international community for urgent additional support for the South Sudan refugee situation, UNHCR said that the funding shortfall in Uganda is now significantly impacting its ability to deliver life-saving aid and key basic services.\n\n\"With refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short. For Uganda, 674 million U.S. dollars is needed for South Sudanese refugees this year, but so far only a fifth of this amount has been received,\" the refugee agency said in a statement issued Thursday.\n\nUganda and the UN in June held a fundraising meeting to raise money to cater to the refugees.\n\n\"In June, the World Food Programme was forced to cut food rations for refugees. Across settlements in northern Uganda, health clinics are being forced to provide vital medical care with too few doctors, healthcare workers and medicines,\" said UNHCR.\n\nAccording to the UN agency, more than 85 percent of the refugees who have arrived in Uganda are women and children.\n\nMoreover, recent arrivals continue to spark violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls, and the kidnapping of boys for forced conscription.\n\nUN figures showed that since {"timeCrawl": "09:36:00", "uri": "710796230", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T09:36:00Z", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "source": {"title": "The Sudanese Media Centre", "uri": "smc.sd", "id": "7528"}, "url": "http://smc.sd/en/south-sudan-refugees-uganda-pass-1-million-mark-unhcr-renews-call-help/", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "(Agencies)\n\n17 August 2017\n\nUNHCR, the UN Refugee Agency, is today reiterating its call to the international community for urgent additional support for the South Sudan refugee situation and Uganda in particular, where the number of refugees from South Sudan has now reached 1 million.\n\nOver the past 12 months, an average of 1,800 South Sudanese have been arriving in Uganda every day. In addition to the million there, a million or even more South Sudanese refugees are being hosted by Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Democratic Republic of the Congo and Central African Republic.\n\nIn Uganda, more than 85 per cent of the refugees who have arrived there are women and children (below 18 years in age). Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls, and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription.\n\nWith refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short. For Uganda, US$674 million is needed for South Sudanese refugees this year, but so far only a fifth of this amount (21 per cent) has been received. Elsewhere in the region, the picture is only marginally better - in all US$883.5 million is needed for the South Sudan situation, but only US$250 million has been received.\n\nThe funding shortfall in Uganda is now significantly impacting the abilities to deliver life-saving aid and key basic services. In June, the World Food Programme was forced to cut food rations for refugees. Across settlements in northern Uganda, health clinics are being forced to provide vital medical care with too few doctors, healthcare workers and medicines. Schooling, meanwhile is also being impacted. Class sizes often exceed 200 pupils, with some lessons held in the open air. Many refugee children are dropping out of education as the nearest schools are too far away for them to easily access.\n\nSince December 2013, when South Sudan's crisis erupted in Juba, more than two million South Sudanese have fled to neighbouring countries, while another two million people are estimated to be internally displaced.\n\nsource:(http://www.unhcr.org)", "id": "9653624", "details": {"timeCrawl": "00:00:00", "uri": "711171987", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T00:00:00Z", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "source": {"title": "GlobalSecurity.org", "uri": "globalsecurity.org", "id": "5033"}, "url": "http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/news/2017/08/mil-170817-unnews01.htm", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "17 August 2017 - As the number of refugees from South Sudan in Uganda passes one million - the vast majority of whom are women and children - the United Nations refugee agency today reiterated its call for urgent additional support.\n\n\"Over the past 12 months, an average of 1,800 South Sudanese have been arriving in Uganda every day,\" said the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) in a statement to the press.\n\n\"In addition to the million there, a million or even more South Sudanese refugees are being hosted by Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Democratic Republic of the Congo and Central African Republic,\" it added.\n\nMore than 85 per cent of the refugees who have arrived in Uganda are women and children, below age 18 years.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls, and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" emphasized UNHCR, explaining that even as thousands of refugees arrive, aid deliveries are increasingly falling short.\n\nThe UN agency underscored that although $674 million is needed for South Sudanese refugees in Uganda this year, so far only a fifth of this amount, or 21 per cent, has been received.\n\n\"Elsewhere in the region, the picture is only marginally better,\" the statement continued, saying that while a total of $883.5 million is needed for the South Sudan situation, only $250 million has been received.\n\nThe funding shortfall in Uganda is now significantly impacting the abilities to deliver life-saving aid and key basic services.\n\n\"In June, the World Food Programme was forced to cut food rations for refugees. Across settlements in northern Uganda, health clinics are being forced to provide vital medical care with too few doctors, healthcare workers and medicines,\" UNHCR elaborated.\n\nMeanwhile, schooling is also being impacted. Class sizes often exceed 200 pupils, with some lessons held in the open air. Many refugee children are dropping out of education as the nearest schools are too far away for them to easily access.\n\n\"Since December 2013, when South Sudan's crisis erupted in Juba, more than {"timeCrawl": "05:57:00", "uri": "710703568", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T05:57:00Z", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "source": {"title": "Thegardenisland.com", "uri": "thegardenisland.com", "id": "11517"}, "url": "http://thegardenisland.com/news/world/million-south-sudan-refugees-now-in-uganda-un-says/article_d2b473bc-2e33-5803-b3c8-f3cca59d7730.html", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "An average of 1,800 South Sudanese citizens have been arriving daily in Uganda over the past 12 months, the UNHCR said in a statement. Another one million or more South Sudanese are sheltering in Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Congo and Central African Republic.\n\nThe number of people fleeing jumped after deadly fighting again erupted in South Sudan's capital, Juba, in July 2016.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" the statement said.\n\n\"With refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short.\"\n\nA fundraising summit hosted by Uganda in June raised only a fraction of the $2 billion that Ugandan officials have said is needed to sufficiently look after the refugees and the communities hosting them.\n\nMost of the refugees are women and children fleeing violence, often along ethnic lines, since the world's newest country erupted into violence in December 2013.\n\nUgandan refugee officials have repeatedly warned the influx is straining the country's ability to be generous to the refugees, who often are given small plots of land for building temporary shelters and planting crops when they arrive.\n\nThe largest of the settlements hosting refugees from South Sudan, Bidi Bidi, is roughly 230 square kilometers (88.8 sq. miles).\n\nThe World Food Program cut food rations for some refugees amid funding shortages in June.\n\nThe U.N. says at least $674 million is needed to support South Sudanese refugees in Uganda this year, although only a fifth of that amount has been received.\n\nThe money is needed to provide basic services, including stocking clinics with medicines and putting up schools. Aid agencies say classroom sizes in the few available schools often exceed 200 pupils, and other children have dropped out because the nearest schools are located miles away.\n\n\"The funding shortfall in Uganda is now significantly impacting the abilities to deliver life-saving aid and key basic services,\" the UNHCR statement said.\n\nFighting persists in parts of South Sudan despite multiple cease-fire agreements. Rebel forces said Tuesday they had reclaimed their stronghold of Pagak in the northeast, less than a week after being pushed out by government forces.\n\nBoth sides have committed serious rights violations, including murder and rape, against civilians, according to U.N. investigators.", "id": "9620235", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "1 million South Sudan refugees now in {"timeCrawl": "08:10:00", "uri": "710758190", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T08:10:00Z", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "source": {"title": "Mail Online", "uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "id": "214"}, "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4798412/index.html", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "A newly arrived refugee child from South Sudan sleeps on a dirty floor on the Ugandan side of the Ngomoromo border post\n\nSouth Sudan's brutal civil war has forced more than one million people to flee to neighbouring Uganda alone, with another million seeking refuge elsewhere in the region, the UN's refugee agency said Thursday.\n\nThe UNHCR said additional funds were desperately needed to help the refugees flooding into Uganda, adding that most were women and children fleeing \"barbaric violence\".\n\nOver the past year, an average of 1,800 South Sudanese have arrived in Uganda every single day, it said.\n\nSouth Sudan, the world's youngest nation, descended into civil war in December 2013, just two years after it split from the north.\n\nThousands of people have been killed and millions displaced by the violence, which briefly plunged part of the country into famine earlier this year.\n\nIn addition to the one million South Sudanese refugees in Uganda, at least another million have fled to Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, the Democratic Republic of Congo and the Central African Republic, according to UN numbers.\n\nAn additional two million people are estimated to have fled their homes and sought refuge elsewhere in the war-ravaged country.\n\nIn Uganda, more than 85 percent of the South Sudanese refugees are women or children and youths under the age of 18.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls, and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" it said in a statement.\n\nThe UN agency warned that \"with refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is "body": "Geneva, Switzerland | AFP | South Sudan's brutal civil war has forced more than one million people to flee to neighbouring Uganda alone, with another million seeking refuge elsewhere in the region, the UN's refugee agency said Thursday.\n\nThe UNHCR said additional funds were desperately needed to help the refugees flooding into Uganda, adding that most were women and children fleeing \"barbaric violence\".\n\nOver the past year, an average of 1,800 South Sudanese have arrived in Uganda every single day, it said.\n\nSouth Sudan, the world's youngest nation, descended into civil war in December 2013, just two years after it split from the north.\n\nThousands of people have been killed and millions displaced by the violence, which briefly plunged part of the country into famine earlier this year.\n\nIn addition to the one million South Sudanese refugees in Uganda, at least another million have fled to Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, the Democratic Republic of Congo and the Central African Republic, according to UN numbers.\n\nAn additional two million people are estimated to have fled their homes and sought refuge elsewhere in the war-ravaged country.\n\nIn Uganda, more than 85 percent of the South Sudanese refugees are women or children and youths under the age of 18.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls, and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" it said in a statement.\n\nThe UN High Commissioner for Refugees expressed thanks for the great cooperation and support the United Nations, especially the UNHCR, find from the Government of Sudan, commending the good hospitality and care accorded by the Sudanese government and people to the refugees in the country.\n\nHe pointed out that this is not new to Sudan as he had seen this by himself when he had served in the country in the 1980s for assisting the refugees in eastern Sudan.\n\nThe meeting also discussed the return of the Sudanese refugees from Chad and implementation of the tripartite agreement between Sudan, Chad and the U.N. as well as creating conducive environment for the return of the refugees, especially after the great stability that has been realized in Darfur during the past period.\n\nThe Minister of Foreign Affairs, on his part, has lauded the visit of the High Commissioner, considering it as an important indication for the recognition of the international community to the role Sudan plays in the field of hosting of refugees from a number of countries, especially South Sudan, stressing that the international community should live up to its responsibilities towards the refugees and provide the required support to them and the host communities.\n\nThe Minister pointed to the importance of finding a political settlement to the ongoing conflict in South Sudan as the optimum solution to all {"timeCrawl": "21:37:00", "uri": "711126825", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T21:37:00Z", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "source": {"title": "DailySabah", "uri": "dailysabah.com", "id": "1235"}, "url": "https://www.dailysabah.com/africa/2017/08/18/uganda-faces-fastest-growing-refugee-crisis-as-1m-south-sudanese-pour-in", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "The number of South Sudanese refugees in Uganda hit 1 million, the United Nations has said, as hundreds of desperate families pour across the border every day seeking refuge from the civil war\n\nThe number of South Sudanese refugees sheltering in Uganda has reached 1 million, the United Nations said yesterday, a grim milestone for what has become the world's fastest-growing refugee crisis.\n\nUgandan officials said they are overwhelmed by the flow of people fleeing South Sudan's civil war and the U.N. refugee agency urges the international community to donate more for humanitarian assistance.\n\nAn average of 1,800 South Sudanese citizens have been arriving daily in Uganda over the past 12 months, the UNHCR said in a statement. Another 1 million or more South Sudanese are sheltering in Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Congo and Central African Republic.\n\nThe number of people fleeing jumped after deadly fighting again erupted in South Sudan's capital, Juba, in July 2016.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" the statement said.\n\n\"With refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short.\"\n\nThe conflict in South Sudan has created Africa's biggest refugee crisis since the 1994 Rwandan genocide, and U.N. agencies are receiving a fraction of the cash they need to provide food and shelter. But the crowds keep flowing across rickety wooden bridges near the northwestern Ugandan border town of Busia, staggering under the weight of babies and a few pots or bundles of clothing balanced on their heads.\n\nA World Vision official says more aid is needed to ensure refugee children on the move are protected when they arrive in Uganda. Enid Kabasinguzi Ocaya, World Vision's s disaster risk reduction and humanitarian emergency affairs manager in Uganda, said in a statement Thursday that \"there is a fear that they may return to South Sudan and take part in the conflict.\"\n\nWorking in partnership with the United Nations, World Vision is the largest provider of food for refugees in Uganda. Over 85 percent of the South Sudanese refugees sheltering in Uganda are women and children.\n\n\"Two weeks ago my husband's uncle was killed,\" said Stella Taji, as she trudged barefoot over the bridge, a toddler clinging to her hand. \"Since then we've been hiding in the bush. We have nothing.\"\n\nOil-rich South Sudan became the world's youngest nation in 2011, upon its independence from neighboring Sudan, but the elation soon evaporated amid corruption and ethnic divisions.Troops loyal to President Salva Kiir, a Dinka, and forces under former vice president Riek Machar, from the Nuer ethnic group, have battled each other since late 2013, killing tens of thousands and forcing nearly a third of the population of 12 million to flee their homes. The trickle of refugees into Uganda swelled into a river last year after a shaky Western-backed peace deal between Kiir and Machar collapsed within months. The conflict has further fragmented since, breeding a patchwork of militias and briefly plunging parts of the country into famine this year. An August report by South Africa-based South Sudan Human Rights Observatory said 987 civilians were killed in violence across South Sudan between May and July, mostly by government forces.", "id": {"timeCrawl": "16:50:00", "uri": "711005226", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T16:50:00Z", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "source": {"title": "UN News Service Section", "uri": "un.org", "id": "3597"}, "url": "http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=57374", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "17 August 2017 - As the number of refugees from South Sudan in Uganda passes one million - the vast majority of whom are women and children - the United Nations refugee agency today reiterated its call for urgent additional support.\n\n\"In addition to the million there, a million or even more South Sudanese refugees are being hosted by Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Democratic Republic of the Congo and Central African Republic,\" it added.\n\nMore than 85 per cent of the refugees who have arrived in Uganda are women and children, below age 18 years.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls, and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" emphasized UNHCR, explaining that even as thousands of refugees arrive, aid deliveries are increasingly falling short.\n\nThe UN agency underscored that although $674 million is needed for South Sudanese refugees in Uganda this year, so far only a fifth of this amount, or 21 per cent, has been received.\n\n\"Elsewhere in the region, the picture is only marginally better,\" the statement continued, saying that while a total of $883.5 million is needed for the South Sudan situation, only $250 million has been received.\n\nThe funding shortfall in Uganda is now significantly impacting the abilities to deliver life-saving aid and key basic services.\n\n\"In June, the World Food Programme was forced to cut food rations for refugees. Across settlements in northern Uganda, health clinics are being forced to provide vital medical care with too few doctors, healthcare workers and medicines,\" UNHCR elaborated.\n\nMeanwhile, schooling is also being impacted. Class sizes often exceed 200 pupils, with some lessons held in the open air. Many refugee children are dropping out of education as the nearest schools are too far away for them to easily access.\n\n\"Since December 2013, when South Sudan's crisis erupted in Juba, more than {"timeCrawl": "08:57:00", "uri": "710780573", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T08:57:00Z", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "source": {"title": "Naharnet", "uri": "naharnet.com", "id": "2341"}, "url": "http://www.naharnet.com/stories/en/234238", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "South Sudan's brutal civil war has forced more than one million people to flee to neighbouring Uganda alone, with another million seeking refuge elsewhere in the region, the UN's refugee agency said Thursday.\n\nThe UNHCR said additional funds were desperately needed to help the refugees flooding into Uganda, adding that most were women and children fleeing \"barbaric violence\".\n\nOver the past year, an average of 1,800 South Sudanese have arrived in Uganda every single day, it said.\n\nSouth Sudan, the world's youngest nation, descended into civil war in December 2013, just two years after it split from the north.\n\nThousands of people have been killed and millions displaced by the violence, which briefly plunged part of the country into famine earlier this year.\n\nIn addition to the one million South Sudanese refugees in Uganda, at least another million have fled to Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, the Democratic Republic of Congo and the Central African Republic, according to UN numbers.\n\nAn additional two million people are estimated to have fled their homes and sought refuge elsewhere in the war-ravaged country.\n\nIn Uganda, more than 85 percent of the South Sudanese refugees are women or children and youths under the age of 18.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls, and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" it said in a statement.\n\nThe UN agency warned that \"with refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short.\"\n\nUNHCR estimates it will need $674 million (576 million euros) this year alone to help the refugees in {"timeCrawl": "08:02:00", "uri": "710754486", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T08:02:00Z", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "source": {"title": "digitaljournal.com", "uri": "digitaljournal.com", "id": "556"}, "url": "http://www.digitaljournal.com/news/world/more-than-one-million-s-sudan-refugees-in-uganda-un/article/500231", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "South Sudan's brutal civil war has forced more than one million people to flee to neighbouring Uganda alone, with another million seeking refuge elsewhere in the region, the UN's refugee agency said Thursday.\n\nThe UNHCR said additional funds were desperately needed to help the refugees flooding into Uganda, adding that most were women and children fleeing \"barbaric violence\".\n\nOver the past year, an average of 1,800 South Sudanese have arrived in Uganda every single day, it said.\n\nSouth Sudan, the world's youngest nation, descended into civil war in December 2013, just two years after it split from the north.\n\nThousands of people have been killed and millions displaced by the violence, which briefly plunged part of the country into famine earlier this year.\n\nIn addition to the one million South Sudanese refugees in Uganda, at least another million have fled to Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, the Democratic Republic of Congo and the Central African Republic, according to UN numbers.\n\nAn additional two million people are estimated to have fled their homes and sought refuge elsewhere in the war-ravaged country.\n\nIn Uganda, more than 85 percent of the South Sudanese refugees are women or children and youths under the age of 18.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls, and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" it said in a statement.\n\nThe UN agency warned that \"with refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short.\"\n\nUNHCR estimates it will need $674 million (576 million euros) this year alone to help the refugees in Uganda, but lamented that so far it had received just a fifth of that amount.\n\n\"The funding shortfall in Uganda is now significantly impacting the abilities to deliver life-saving aid and key basic services,\" it said.\n\nIn June, The UN's World Food Programme had to slash food rations for refugees in the country, while doctors, nurses and medicines are in short supply, it said.\n\nSchooling has also been affected, with class sizes often exceeding 200 pupils, teachers forced to hold lessons outdoors, and many refugee children dropping {"timeCrawl": "08:33:00", "uri": "710770229", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T08:33:00Z", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "source": {"title": "middle-east-online.com", "uri": "middle-east-online.com", "id": "15257"}, "url": "http://www.middle-east-online.com/english/?id=84375", "eventUri": "eng-3368153", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368153", "body": "GENEVA - South Sudan's brutal civil war has forced more than one million people to flee to neighbouring Uganda alone, with another million seeking refuge elsewhere in the region, the UN's refugee agency said Thursday.\n\nThe UNHCR said additional funds were desperately needed to help the refugees flooding into Uganda, adding that most were women and children fleeing \"barbaric violence\".\n\nOver the past year, an average of 1,800 South Sudanese have arrived in Uganda every single day, it said.\n\nSouth Sudan, the world's youngest nation, descended into civil war in December 2013, just two years after it split from the north.\n\nThousands of people have been killed and millions displaced by the violence, which briefly plunged part of the country into famine earlier this year.\n\nIn addition to the one million South Sudanese refugees in Uganda, at least another million have fled to Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, the Democratic Republic of Congo and the Central African Republic, according to UN numbers.\n\nAn additional two million people are estimated to have fled their homes and sought refuge elsewhere in the war-ravaged country.\n\nIn Uganda, more than 85 percent of the South Sudanese refugees are women or children and youths under the age of 18.\n\n\"Recent arrivals continue to speak of barbaric violence, with armed groups reportedly burning down houses with civilians inside, people being killed in front of family members, sexual assaults of women and girls, and kidnapping of boys for forced conscription,\" it said in a statement.\n\nThe UN agency warned that \"with refugees still arriving in their thousands, the amount of aid we are able to deliver is increasingly falling short.\"\n\nUNHCR estimates it will need $674 million (576 million euros) this year alone to help the refugees in Uganda, but lamented that so far it had received just a fifth of that amount.\n\n\"The funding shortfall in Uganda is now significantly impacting the abilities to deliver life-saving aid and key basic services,\" it said.\n\nIn June, The UN's World Food Programme had to slash food rations for refugees in the country, while doctors, nurses and medicines are in short supply, it said.\n\nSchooling has also been affected, with class sizes often exceeding 200 pupils, teachers forced to hold lessons outdoors, and many refugee children dropping
